revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox writer | name = A. M. Homes | image = A M Homes by David Shankbone.jpg | imagesize = | caption = A. M. Homes | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1961|12|18}} | birth_place = Washington, D.C., US | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Fiction writer, [[memoir]]ist, screenwriter | nationality = American | period = 1989 – present | genre = | subject = | movement = | notableworks =
''[[The End of Alice]]'' (1996) | spouse = | partner = | children = Juliet Homes | relatives = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | website = {{URL|http://www.amhomesbooks.com/}} | portaldisp = }} '''Amy M. Homes''' (pen name '''A. M. Homes'''; born December 18, 1961,[[Library of Congress]] [[authority control|authority record]]. Retrieved on November 11, 2007. Washington, D.C.) is an American writer best known for her controversial novels and unusual short stories, which feature extreme situations and characters. Notably, her novel ''[[The End of Alice]]'' (1996) depicts a convicted [[child sexual abuse|child molester]] and murderer. Homes, who was adopted at birth, met her biological parents for the first time when she was 31, and published a memoir, ''The Mistress's Daughter'' (2007) about her exploration of her expanded "family". {{As of|2018|alt=Her most recent novel|post=,}} ''[[May We Be Forgiven]],'' was published by [[Viking Books]] on September 27, 2012. The first chapter of the novel was published in the 100th issue of ''[[Granta]]'' (in 2008; edited by [[William Boyd (writer)|William Boyd]]), and was selected by [[Salman Rushdie]] for ''[[The Best American Short Stories 2008]]''. The novel won the [[Baileys Women's Prize for Fiction|Women's Prize for Fiction]] in 2013. ==Early life== Homes was born in 1961 in Washington, DC to a single woman who got pregnant during an affair with her older, married boss. Homes was put up for adoption immediately after birth and reared by her adoptive parents in the Washington metropolitan area. She did not meet her biological parents until she was 31, when her mother first tracked her down. Homes received her Bachelor of Arts in 1985 from [[Sarah Lawrence College]],Weich, Dave, "A. M. Homes Is a Big Fat Liar," Powells.com, May 24, 1999. where she studied with the author [[Grace Paley]]. She earned her [[Master of Fine Arts]] from the [[Iowa Writers Workshop|University of Iowa Writers' Workshop]].https://writersworkshop.uiowa.edu/resources/news/am-homes-wins-womens-prize-fiction ==Career== ===Fiction=== Homes has written both short stories and novels; the former published in leading magazines such as ''Granta,'' ''The New Yorker'', ''[[Timothy McSweeney's Quarterly Concern|McSweeney's]],'' and ''[[BOMB Magazine]]''. She wrote her first novel, ''[[Jack (A.M. Homes novel)|Jack]]'', when she was 19; it was published in 1989 when she was 28, after she had published some short stories. An exploration of family life and sexuality, it features a boy with divorced parents who learns that his father is gay. The book was critically praised and is still featured in school and college reading lists.[http://www.barcelonareview.com/eng/eng4b4.htm Jill Adams, "An Interview with A.M. Homes"], ''The Barcelona Review'', Jun/July 2007, #58/59, accessed 31 May 2014 Homes wrote a screenplay to adapt it as a film by the same name, produced in 2004 for the cable network [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]]. A year later, her first short-story collection, ''[[The Safety of Objects]]'' (1990), was published. This was adapted as an independent [[The Safety of Objects|feature film]] of the same name, released in 2001 and starring [[Glenn Close]] among others. Homes co-wrote the screenplay together with the director, [[Rose Troche]]. Her second novel was ''In a Country of Mothers'' (1993). It centered around a therapist and a girl patient who was adopted; the therapist begins to think the girl might be her own daughter, whom she had given up at birth. (Homes was writing this novel and it was in production before her own birth mother tracked her down in 1992.) Homes' 1996 novel, ''[[The End of Alice]],'' is narrated mostly by a convicted [[child sexual abuse|child molester]] and murderer imprisoned in the West Block of [[Sing Sing]]. The [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning author [[Michael Cunningham]] described this work as
dark and treacherous as ice on a highway. It establishes A. M. Homes as one of the bravest, most terrifying writers working today. She never plays it safe, and it begins to look as if she can do almost anything.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}}
It aroused considerable controversy and received mixed reviews because of its subject matter and objectionable protagonists; in the UK, bookseller [[W.H. Smith]] refused to carry it. Homes published the first chapter of her 1999 novel ''[[Music for Torching]]'' as a short story in ''The New Yorker.'' The novel features characters who appeared in the short stories of her first collection, ''The Safety of Objects.'' It features a suburban couple who deliberately burn their house down. Jill Adams in ''The Barcelona Review'' described it as having Homes' "trademark style of wry humor applied to the uncanny dissection of suburbia’s facade." Britain's ''[[The Observer]]'' found it "immensely disturbing".Clark, Alex. "Book Burns Night", ''The Observer,'' 22 August 1999. ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine called the novel "haunting,",Hubbard, Kim, People, "Music For Torching", June 28, 1999. [[Gary Krist (writer)|Gary Krist]] in ''[[The New York Times]]'' described it as a
nasty and willfully grotesque novel. The fact is, I was at times appalled by the book, annoyed by it, angered by it. Its ending struck me as cynical and manipulative. But even so, I found myself rapt from beginning to end, fascinated by Homes's single-minded talent for provocation."[https://www.nytimes.com/1999/05/30/books/burning-down-the-house.html Krist, Gary, "Burning Down The House"], ''The New York Times'', May 30, 1999.
He concluded with a caveat: "In her last two novels, the desire to outrage is so conspicuous that it risks obscuring her powerful gifts as a novelist." Writing in ''[[The Guardian]]'' in 2003, the writer [[Ali Smith]] described Homes' second short story collection, ''[[Things You Should Know]],'' as "funny and glinting and masterful, light as air, strange as a dream, monstrous as truth: the real and classic thing."Smith, Ali, ''The Guardian,'' "Fertile Ground: Ali Smith revels in A. M. Homes' Masterful Short Stories", May 21, 2003. Her novel, ''This Book Will Save Your Life'' (2006), was set in Los Angeles; it satirized upper-class residents and the city's culture. It featured "a rich, isolated man who suffers a physical crisis and goes on a wild compassion spree." ''[[The Guardian]]'' said that "it was kitschy and bordered on the inane, but there was something appealing about its mixture of the apocalyptic and the perkily upbeat, caught nicely by [[John Waters]] when he said: 'If Oprah went insane, this might be her favourite book.'"[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/oct/19/may-we-be-forgiven-am-homes-review Theo Tait, "'May We Be Forgiven' by AM Homes - review"], ''The Guardian,'' 19 October 2012, accessed 1 June 2014 With ''[[May We Be Forgiven]]'' (2012), Homes returned to a setting in [[Westchester County, New York]], the region described in several of her novels. Packed with violent, emotional incident in the first chapter, it won the [[Women's Prize for Fiction]] (formerly the Orange Prize), awarded in the United Kingdom.''The Guardian'' review described it as "a novel about forgiveness, family, intimacy, consumerism and the myth of success." The reviewer said, "AM Homes can't really be compared to any other writer; no one else is quite as dark and funny and elegant all at the same time."[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/oct/14/am-homes-be-forgiven-review Viv Groskop, "'May We Be Forgiven' by AM Homes-review"], ''The Guardian'', 14 October 2012 ===Journalism=== Homes' articles and essays are published in magazines such as ''[[The New Yorker]]'', ''[[Artforum]]'', ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'', and ''[[Timothy McSweeney's Quarterly Concern|McSweeney's]]'', among others. She has also been a contributing editor to ''[[BOMB Magazine]]'' since 1995, where she has published articles and interviews with various artists and writers, including [[Eric Fischl]], [[Tobias Wolff]], and [[Adam Bartos]].[http://bombsite.com/articles/search?search=a.m.+homes Bombsite.com A. M. Holmes articles] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110502074720/http://bombsite.com/articles/search?search=a.m.+homes |date=May 2, 2011 }}, at [[BOMB (magazine)|BOMB]], Retrieved June 28, 2010. In 2004, ''[[The New Yorker]]'' published "The Mistress's Daughter", her essay about meeting her biological parents for the first time at age 31; unmarried when she was born, they had immediately put her up for [[adoption]]. She expanded the essay about exploration of her "family" members and published her memoir in 2007.{{cite web|url=http://movies.msn.com/news/article.aspx?news=224351|date=May 28, 2006|accessdate=March 8, 2007|title=A. M. Homes Throws Readers a Life Preserver|work=[[MSN]] Entertainment}} ===Television=== Homes wrote for season two of the television drama series, ''[[The L Word]],'' and produced season three. She developed an [[HBO]] series, ''The Hamptons'' about the resort towns along the ocean on eastern Long Island, which she described as "a cross between ''[[Desperate Housewives]]'' and ''[[The Grapes of Wrath (film)|Grapes of Wrath]]''."{{Citation needed|date=July 2007}} Since 2010, Homes has been developing television pilots for CBS with Timberman/Beverly Productions. In 2013 she was developing [[Koethi Zan]]'s best-selling novel, ''The Never List,'' as a dramatic series for CBS television.{{cite web|last=Goldberg|first=Lesley|title=OCT 17 6 DAYS CBS Adapting Koethi Zan's Best-Seller 'The Never List'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/cbs-adapting-koethi-zans-best-649145|work=10/17/2013|publisher=''Hollywood Reporter''}} Homes was a writer and Co-Executive Producer on the 2017 USA Series Falling Water, and also a writer and Co-Executive Producer on the David Kelly Stephen King Series, Mr. Mercedes.IMDB https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0392977/ ==Personal life== Homes lives in New York City with her daughter, Juliet, born in 2003. She has taught in the writing programs at [[Columbia University]], [[The New School]], and [[New York University]].Lyceum Speakers Agency, [http://www.lyceumagency.com/a_m_+homes.aspx "A.M. Homes"], Lyceum Agency website, retrieved 3-20-2008 In 2008 she was teaching in the Creative Writing Program at [[Princeton University]]. In her memoir ''The Mistress's Daughter'', Homes describes meeting her birth parents for the first time when she was 31. They were unmarried when she was born and put her up for adoption. Her birth mother Ellen Ballman was having an affair with her much older, married boss Norman Hecht when she became pregnant. Ballman initiated contact with Homes in hopes that her daughter might donate a kidney to her. Homes also met the members of her father's "legal" family. Asked about her sexuality, Homes said in an April 2007 interview in the ''[[Washington Post]]'', "I've dated men and I've dated women and there's no more or less to it than that."[http://www.afterellen.com/people/2007/5/amhomes "Catching up with A. M. Homes"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012065607/http://www.afterellen.com/people/2007/5/amhomes |date=October 12, 2012 }}, Afterellen.com. Retrieved May 29, 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.amhomesbooks.com/index.php?mode=objectlist§ion_id=137&object_id=293 |title=A. M. Homes – Author Interviews |publisher=Amhomesbooks.com |date= |accessdate=December 4, 2013}} In an interview with ''Diva'' magazine, she said, "I am bisexual, but I wouldn't necessarily define myself that way."[http://www.divamag.co.uk/diva/features.asp?PID=37647 "Interview with A.M. Homes"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110226073037/http://www.divamag.co.uk/diva/features.asp?PID=37647 |date=February 26, 2011 }}, ''Diva'' magazine Once a guest artist at the artists' collective [[Yaddo]], Homes was named as its co-chairwoman with [[Susan Unterberg]] in 2013. On this, she stated, "Without Yaddo, I wouldn't exist as a writer. Yaddo gives artists the increasingly rare gift of a time and place to do one's work, suspended from the intrusive buzz of the every day. I am forever indebted."{{Cite news|url=http://www.saratogian.com/article/ST/20130909/NEWS/309099983|title=Yaddo board elects two artists to share chairmanship|last=|first=|date=2013-09-09|work=Saratogian News|access-date=2018-07-27|language=en}} ==Awards== Homes has received numerous awards, including a [[Guggenheim Fellowship]], a [[National Endowment for the Arts]] Fellowship, a Cullman Center Fellowship from the [[New York Public Library]], a [[Center for Scholars and Writers]] Fellowship, [[National Foundation for the Arts]] and [[New York Foundation for the Arts]] fellowships, and the [[Deutscher Jugendliteraturpreis]]. Her work has been translated into 22 languages.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} In June 2013, she won the prestigious [[Women's Prize for Fiction]]Women's Prize for Fiction{{cite web|title=Winner – Women's Prize for Fiction|url=http://www.womensprizeforfiction.co.uk/2013-prize/2013-winner|access-date=June 5, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130621054106/http://www.womensprizeforfiction.co.uk/2013-prize/2013-winner|archive-date=June 21, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} (formerly named the Orange Prize for Fiction) for her novel ''[[May We Be Forgiven]]'' (2012). ==Bibliography== {{Expand list|date=June 2016}} ===Books=== ====Novels==== * ''[[Jack (A.M. Homes novel)|Jack]]'' (1989) * ''[[In a Country of Mothers]]'' (1993) * ''[[The End of Alice]]'' (1996) * ''[[Appendix A: an elaboration on the novel The End of Alice]]'' (1996) * ''[[Music for Torching]]'' (1999) * ''[[This Book Will Save Your Life]]'' (2006) * ''[[May We Be Forgiven]]'' (2012) ====Story collections==== * ''[[The Safety of Objects (stories)|The Safety of Objects]]'' (1990) * ''[[Things You Should Know (stories)|Things You Should Know]]'' (2002) * ''Days of Awe'' (2018) ====Non-fiction==== * ''[[Los Angeles: People, Places, and the Castle on the Hill]]'' (2002) * ''On the Street 1980–1990'' by [[Amy Arbus]], Introduction by Homes * ''[[The Mistress's Daughter]]'' (2007) ===Essays and reporting=== *{{cite journal |author=Homes, A. M. |authorlink= |authormask= |date=Jun 2013 |title=Curious George |department=Spotlight |journal=Vanity Fair |volume=634 |issue= |pages=105 |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/2013/06/george-plimpton-paris-review-wasp-zelig |}} *{{cite journal |author=Homes, A. M. |authorlink= |authormask= |date=Jun 2018 |title=On Writing Letters to Famous Strangers |department=Essays |journal=the PARIS REVIEW |url=https://www.theparisreview.org/blog/2018/06/27/on-writing-letters-to-famous-strangers/ |}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} *[http://www.amhomesbooks.com/ Official Website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060208235848/http://www.powells.com/authors/homes.html Powells interview with A. M. Homes] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090403085154/http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/collective/A12480941 Interview with A. M. Homes], BBC ''Collective'' *{{IMDb name|0392977|A. M. Homes}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Homes, A. M.}} [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century American novelists]] [[Category:21st-century American novelists]] [[Category:American adoptees]] [[Category:American women short story writers]] [[Category:American women novelists]] [[Category:Bisexual women]] [[Category:Bisexual writers]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]] [[Category:Iowa Writers' Workshop alumni]] [[Category:LGBT writers from the United States]] [[Category:Sarah Lawrence College alumni]] [[Category:Vanity Fair (magazine) people]] [[Category:Writers from New York City]] [[Category:Novelists from New York (state)]] [[Category:LGBT novelists]] [[Category:20th-century American women writers]] [[Category:21st-century American women writers]] [[Category:20th-century American short story writers]] [[Category:21st-century American short story writers]] [[Category:Novelists from Washington, D.C.]]

revision.text:
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:AGSEP3.jpg|thumb|325px|German students giving swimming training to children at a Peace Village in Sri Lanka]] -->
'''Asian-German Sports Exchange Program''' (AGSEP), is a [[non-governmental organisation]] operating in the development sector in [[Sri Lanka]] with a partner office in [[Essen]], [[Germany]]. AGSEP describes itself as Government Associated Organisation because of its consultancy status to the Sri Lankan Ministry of Disaster Relief Services and the Ministry for Rehabilitation & District Development.
==Profile== AGSEP works with volunteers; mainly with students from leading German universities doing undergraduate and postgraduate studies in the fields of [[economics]], [[political science]], [[social science]], [[engineering]], [[sport]] and other disciplines. The Asian German Sports Exchange Programme (A.G.S.E.P.)has been conducting sport events and international exchanges between Sri Lankan and European sport teams since 1989. The organisation is based in Marawila, in rural western Sri Lanka, and was founded by the current CEO of the programme, Dr. Dietmar Döring, who at that time was the national coach of the table tennis team. Dr. Döring saw an opportunity to use sport events as an avenue to enhance tourism and the relationships between estranged ethnic communities in Sri Lanka. The philosophy of A.G.S.E.P. is that sport is an ideal way of connecting people and transcending social, cultural, ethnic and religious cleavages. Sport provides a neutral platform for all participants, who are able to experience and learn from each other in a playful and open atmosphere.
AGSEP's mission it to assist the divided ethnic groups of Sri Lanka to find peace by exposing the children of the island to children of other ethnic groups as part of sporting events.<ref name=PeaceFed>{{cite web|url=http://peacefederation.org/news/field/asia/2006/index.php?report_id=817&event_id=169 |title=Sri Lanka, gets an Inter-Cultural Peace Sports Centre |accessdate=2007-03-10 |last=Senaratne |first=Chula |date=August 9, 2006 |publisher=UPF/IIFWP }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name=Praktikum>{{cite web|url=http://www.praktikum.info/arbeitgeber/1639/Asien_German_Sports_Exchange_Programme_(A.G.S.E.P.).html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090517084031/http://www.praktikum.info/arbeitgeber/1639/Asien_German_Sports_Exchange_Programme_(A.G.S.E.P.).html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2009-05-17 |title=Asien German Sports Exchange Programme (A.G.S.E.P.) |accessdate=2007-03-10 |publisher=praktikum.info |language=German }}</ref>
==History== The German social education worker Dietmar Doering founded AGSEP while he was a national coach for the table tennis team of Sri Lanka.
Since 1989, against the background of a long-lasting civil war, AGSEP has promoted integrative sport events as peaceful intergroup sport encounters that popularise social values such as intercultural togetherness, respect, courage, commitment, and appreciation through active participation and exchange. Integrative sport events are planned, organised, implemented and staged in co-operation with the three major ethnic groups on the island, [[Sinhalese people|Sinhalese]], [[Tamil people|Tamil]]s and [[Muslim]]s.
[[File:German Tsunami Relief Mission Team in Mullaitivu.jpg|thumb|275px|German tsunami relief mission team members of AGSEP visiting tsunami-hit [[Mullaitivu]] in Sri Lanka in January, 2005]]
==Activities== ===Tsunami relief mission===
AGSEP imported more than five million US dollars worth of medicines directly from Germany and distributed them to areas affected by the [[2004 tsunami]].<ref name=Kanagasigam>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynews.lk/2005/12/06/fea02.htm |title=German hamlet of Asia |accessdate=2007-03-10 |last=Kanagasingam |first=Rajkumar |date=December 6, 2005 |work=Sri Lanka Daily News |publisher=The Associated Newspapers of Ceylon Ltd. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930013135/http://www.dailynews.lk/2005/12/06/fea02.htm |archivedate=2007-09-30 |df= }}</ref><ref name=Tsunami-swept>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailynews.lk/2005/01/19/fea03.html |title=A visit to the tsunami-swept North |accessdate=2007-03-10 |last=Kanagasingam |first=Rajkumar |date=January 19, 2005 |work=Sri Lanka Daily News |publisher=The Associated Newspapers of Ceylon Ltd. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930033740/http://www.dailynews.lk/2005/01/19/fea03.html |archivedate=2007-09-30 |df= }}</ref>
===International Run for Peace=== AGSEP organized the International Run for Peace in Sri Lanka in its bid to promote a lasting peace in the war-torn island.<ref name=RunForPeace>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynews.lk/2005/06/02/spo04.htm |title=Three thousand Lankan athletes for International Run for Peace |accessdate=2007-03-10 |date=June 2, 2005 |work=Sri Lanka Daily News |publisher=The Associated Newspapers of Ceylon Ltd. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927190702/http://www.dailynews.lk/2005/06/02/spo04.htm |archivedate=September 27, 2007 }}</ref>
===International Master Games in Sri Lanka=== [[File:Master Games Sri Lanka.jpg|thumb|275px|Master Games Sri Lanka]]
AGSEP organizes International Master Games in Sri Lanka where competitors from a number of countries used to take part.<ref name=MasterGames>{{cite web |url=http://www.ttasl.org/news-paper-articles/srilankatohostmastersgames-dailynews02112010 |title=Sri Lanka to host Masters Games - Daily News 02.11.2010 |accessdate=2011-06-07 |date=November 2, 2010 |work=Sri Lanka Daily News |publisher=Table Tennis Association of Sri Lanka }}</ref>
Players between the ages of 30 to 70 years used to take part in table [[tennis]], [[badminton]], [[football]], [[handball]] and [[beach soccer]] [[tournaments]] which will be played in towns such as [[Negombo]], [[Kandy]], [[Trincomalee]], [[Galle]], [[Marawila]], [[Puttalam]] and [[Hambantota]]. <ref name=MasterGames></ref>
Teams from [[Germany]], [[France]], [[Italy]], [[Norway]], [[Netherlands]], [[Belgium]], [[Luxembourg]], [[England]], [[Austria]], [[Switzerland]], [[Sweden]], [[Scotland]], [[Finland]], [[Denmark]], [[Poland]], [[Russia]], [[Ireland]] and Asian countries [[Japan]], [[China]], [[Malaysia]], [[India]], [[Pakistan]], [[Maldives]], [[Taiwan]], [[Sri Lanka]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Singapore]], [[Indonesia]], [[South Korea]], [[Vietnam]] and [[Canada]] will compete in the Masters Games.<ref name=MasterGames></ref>
[[File:Front Cover German Memories in Asia.JPG|thumb|150px|left|''German Memories in Asia'', front page]]
==''German Memories in Asia''== ''German Memories in Asia'' is a collection of memories by the author Rajkumar Kanagasingam, in his discussions with the German university students, who have been volunteering in Asia under [[internship]] programs; and a collection of facts by the author by further research on the discussed subjects. It narrates Asian and European historical events, especially the German, since the [[Roman Empire]] era and about the Germans in Germany, [[Latin America]], [[North America]], [[East Europe]]an countries, [[Australia]] and elsewhere in the world and their migrations, life styles, encounters and [[Cultural assimilation|assimilation]] since ancient times.
The author analyses the [[Franco-Prussian War]] and the [[Otto von Bismarck]]'s diplomacy, [[Austria]] & the divided German states, [[German-Brazilian]]s today, the [[Pennsylvania]]'s [[Amish]] county & the [[Mennonite]] communities, the [[List of former German colonies|German colonies in Africa, Asia and the Pacific]], [[Volga Germans]] in Russia under [[Bolshevist]] atrocities and the First and Second World War issues of [[Kaiser William II]] and his diplomatic chaos, [[Bombing of Dresden in World War II|Firebombing on Dresden]], [[Danube Swabian]]s and their expulsion, the U.S. President Gen. [[Dwight D Eisenhower]] in the crisis of starving German [[POW]]s and more.
The book explores the author's encounters in his early days in the war-ravaged [[Jaffna]] in the northern part of Sri Lanka, and then in a [[tsunami]] relief mission there with German universities' internship students.{{clear left}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.agsep.com Official website] {{de icon}}

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Musical organisations based in Australia‎ to [[:Category:Music organisations based in Australia‎]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 October 9]].
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=June 2015}} [[Image:AMEB logo.png|right|125px]] The '''Australian Music Examinations Board''' ('''AMEB''') is a federated, privately funded corporation which provides a program of examinations for music, speech and drama in Australia. The organisation had its beginnings at the Universities of Melbourne and Adelaide in 1887 and now has six state offices as well as a Federal Office in Melbourne. The Federal Board consists of representatives of educational institutions that are signatories to the AMEB constitution. These are the Universities of Melbourne, Adelaide and Western Australia, the Minister for Education and Training, New South Wales, the Minister for Education, Training and Employment, Queensland and the Minister for Education and Skills, Tasmania through the University of Tasmania.
AMEB examinations are based on syllabuses set by the Federal Board in conjunction with the music and speech and drama community. AMEB produces a range of publications which support students and teachers preparing for exams.
AMEB offers syllabuses and examinations in a broad range of subjects including:
* Music Teaching * Music Theory (Theory of Music, Musicianship, Music Craft) * Keyboard (Piano, Piano for Leisure, P Plate Piano, Organ, Electronic Organ) * Strings (Violin, Viola, Cello, Double Bass, Classical Guitar, Harp) * Woodwind (Recorder, Flute, Oboe, Clarinet, Bassoon, Saxophone, Saxophone for Leisure) * Brass (Horn, Trumpet, Trombone, Bass Trombone, Tuba, Euphonium) * Brass Band Instruments (Instruments in B flat, E flat and C) * Percussion * Voice (Singing, Singing for Leisure) * Contemporary Popular Music (Keyboard, Vocal, Drum Kit, Guitar, Bass) * Musical Ensembles (Brass, Mixed, Percussion, Strings, Woodwind) * Speech and Drama
AMEB examinations cover a large range of skill levels; from a "Preliminary" grade suitable for very young children through to [[academic degree]]-level diplomas, including the ''[[Associate in Music, Australia|Associate in Music]]'' (AMusA), the ''[[Licentiate in Music, Australia|Licentiate in Music]]'' (LMusA), and ultimately the ''[[Fellowship in Music, Australia|Fellowship in Music]]'' (FMusA), a diploma that is often conferred on an honorary basis to musical luminaries.
AMEB has recently introduced online examinations for music theory and online courses for Theory of Music.
In addition to the standard syllabuses, AMEB has a series of "for leisure" syllabuses for the piano, saxophone and voice which contain a repertoire of modern music. AMEB also has a Contemporary Popular Music (CPM) offering for Keyboard, Drum Kit, Guitar, Bass and Voice.
==External links== *[http://www.ameb.edu.au Official website]
[[Category:Performing arts education in Australia]] [[Category:Music education organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1887]] [[Category:Music organisations based in Australia]]
{{australia-edu-stub}} {{music-education-stub}}

{{Infobox Korean name | hangul = 한문 교육용 기초 한자 | hanja = {{lang|ko|漢文敎育用基礎漢字}} | rr = hanmun gyoyukyong gicho Hanja | mr = hanmun'gyoyugyong kich'o hancha }} '''Hanmun gyoyukyong gicho Hanja''' (lit. "basic [[Hanja]] for educational use") are a subset of Hanja defined in 1972 by a South Korean standard for educational use. 900 characters are expected to be learnt by middle school students and a further 900 at high school.{{cite book |title=CJKV Information Processing |authorlink=Ken Lunde |last=Lunde |first=Ken |page=84 |year=2008 |publisher=[[O'Reilly Media]] |isbn=978-0-596-51447-1 }} ==List of characters== *Each [[hanja]] is sorted by the alphabetical order of the Sino-Korean reading. *The "Grades" column indicates whether the character is taught in Middle School (grades 7–9) or High School (grades 10–12). *For brevity, only one English translation is given per [[hanja]]. *The "Readings" column shows the Native Korean reading of the character first, followed by the Sino-Korean reading. Underneath the [[hangul]] forms are the Latin renditions according to the [[Revised_Romanization_of_Korean|Revised Romanization]], followed by a [[Hangul_consonant_and_vowel_tables|jamo]]-by-jamo transliteration without special provisions made for more accurate representation of phonology, but rather of spelling. *This list is currently incomplete. {|class="sortable wikitable" style="font-family:'Noto Sans CJK KR','Arial Unicode MS','Droid Sans Fallback','Droid Sans','AppleGothic','Apple SD Gothic Neo','Baekmuk Gulim','Dotum','DotumChe','Gulim','GulimChe','Hamchorom Dotum','Jieubsida Dodum','Malgun Gothic','Nanum Gothic','New Gulim','Seoul Namsan','UnDotum','UnShinmun';" |-style="line-height:1.4em" !# !Initial [[Hangul_consonant_and_vowel_tables|jamo]] ![[Hangul]] ![[Hanja]] ![[Radical_(Chinese_characters)|Radical]] !Grades !English meaning !Readings |- |style="text-align: right;"|1||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:ㄱ|ㄱ]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:가|가]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:家|家]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[Radical_40|宀]]||[[Education_in_South_Korea#Middle_school|7–9]]||house||집　가

''keul geo'' (''keul geo'') |- |style="text-align: right;"|55||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:ㄱ|ㄱ]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:거|거]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:居|居]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[Radical_44|尸]]||[[Education_in_South_Korea#Middle_school|7–9]]||living||있을　거
''sal geo'' (''sal geo'') |- |style="text-align: right;"|56||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:ㄱ|ㄱ]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:거|거]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:車|車]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[Radical_159|車]]||[[Education_in_South_Korea#Middle_school|7–9]]||vehicle||수레　거
''sure geo'' (''sule geo'') |- |style="text-align: right;"|57||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:ㄱ|ㄱ]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:거|거]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:擧|擧]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[Radical_64|手]]||[[Education_in_South_Korea#Middle_school|7–9]]||lifting||들　거
''deul geo'' (''deul geo'') |- |style="text-align: right;"|58||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:ㄱ|ㄱ]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:거|거]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:距|距]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[Radical_157|足]]||[[Education_in_South_Korea#Middle_school|10–12]]||falling||떨어질　거
''tteoreojil geo'' (''tteoleojil geo'') |- |style="text-align: right;"|59||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:ㄱ|ㄱ]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:거|거]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:拒|拒]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[Radical_64|手]]||[[Education_in_South_Korea#Middle_school|10–12]]||blockage||막을　거
''mageul geo'' (''mageul geo'') |- |style="text-align: right;"|60||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:ㄱ|ㄱ]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:거|거]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[wikt:據|據]]||style="font-size:2em"|[[Radical_64|手]]||[[Education_in_South_Korea#Middle_school|10–12]]||dependence||의거할　거
''uijihal geo'' (''uijihal geo'') |} ==See also== *[https://ko.wiktionary.org/wiki/%EB%B6%80%EB%A1%9D:%ED%95%9C%EB%AC%B8_%EA%B5%90%EC%9C%A1%EC%9A%A9_%EA%B8%B0%EC%B4%88_%ED%95%9C%EC%9E%90_1800 Middle and high school Hanja list] *[[Kyōiku kanji]] *[[Jōyō kanji]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Wiktionary|:ko:부록:한문 교육용 기초 한자 1800}} [[Category:Hanja]] [[Category:Education in Korea]]

{{multiple issues| {{close paraphrasing|date=June 2017}} {{notability|date=June 2017}} {{primary sources|date=June 2017}} {{third-party|date=June 2017}} }} {{Infobox journal | title = Berkeley Review of Education | abbreviation = Berkeley Rev. Educ. | cover = | editor = | discipline = [[Education]] | language = English | publisher = [[California Digital Library]] | country = United States | frequency = Biannual | history = 2010-Present | peer-reviewed = yes | openaccess = yes | link1 = http://www.berkeleyreviewofeducation.com/ | link1-name = Journal website | link2 = https://escholarship.org/uc/ucbgse_bre | link2-name = Online access | website = | JSTOR = | OCLC = | LCCN = | CODEN = | ISSN = 1947-5578 | eISSN = }} Founded in 2010<ref> {{Cite web|url=https://escholarship.org/uc/search?entity=ucbgse_bre;volume=1;issue=1|title=BRE first issue|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref>, the '''''Berkeley Review of Education''''' (BRE) is an open-access online academic journal edited by students at the [[UC Berkeley Graduate School of Education]]<ref> {{Cite web|url=https://escholarship.org/uc/search?entity=ucbgse_bre;view=aboutus|title=BRE first about-us page|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref>. The journal publishes articles that address issues of educational diversity and equity from various intra/interdisciplinary perspectives<ref> {{Cite web|url=http://www.berkeleyreviewofeducation.com/|title=BRE home page|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref>, with two issues each year.
The journal also hosts a [http://www.berkeleyreviewofeducation.com/call-for-conversations-home.html Call for Conversations] on its website.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.berkeleyreviewofeducation.com}} * [http://www.berkeleyreviewofeducation.com/call-for-conversations-home.html Call for Conversations] * [https://escholarship.org/uc/ucbgse_bre Online access]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Use Indian Hindi|date=February 2017}} {{More citations needed|date=August 2017}}
{{Infobox project | name = BetiPadao Yojana Scheme 2015/2019 | image = Beti Bachao Beti Padhao.jpg | country = India | primeminister = Narendra Modi | ministry = A joint initiative of [[Ministry of Women and Child Development|MoWCD]], [[Ministry of Health and Family Welfare|MoHFW]] and [[Ministry of Human Resource Development|MoHRD]] | launched = {{start date and age|2015|01|22|df=y}} | current_status = Active }} '''Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao''' ''(translation: ''Save girl child, educate a girl child'')'' is a personal campaign of the [[Government of India]] that aims to generate awareness and improve the efficiency of welfare services intended for girls. The scheme was launched with an initial funding of {{INRConvert|100|c}}.<ref name="Beti_bachao_beti_padhao_campaign_24072014"/> It mainly targets the clusters in [[Uttar Pradesh]], [[Haryana]], [[Uttarakhand]], [[Punjab, India|Punjab]], [[Bihar]] and [[Delhi]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/up-govt-sounds-alert-over-beti-bachao-beti-padhao-scheme-fraud/story-Qmns8pm4xqBtFyWNGMuyoI.html|title=UP govt sounds alert over Beti Bachao Beti Padhao scheme fraud|work=[[Hindustan Times]]|author=K Sandeep Kumar, Rajeev Mullick|date=19 May 2017|accessdate=12 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/haryana-govt-cautions-people-against-frauds-under-beti-bachao-beti-padhao-scheme-4589990/|title=Haryana govt cautions people against frauds under Beti Bachao-Beti Padhao scheme|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=28 March 2017|author=[[Press Trust of India]]|accessdate=12 June 2017}}</ref>
According to census data, the [[child gender ratio]] (0–6 years) in India was 927 girls per 1,000 boys in 2001, which dropped to 918<ref name="Beti_bachao_beti_padhao_campaign_24072014"/> girls for every 1,000 boys in 2011. A 2012 [[UNICEF]] report ranked India 41st among 195 countries.{{Citation needed|date=April 2017}} In the Population Census of 2011 it was revealed that the population ratio of India 2011 is 943 females per 1000 of males. The Sex Ratio 2011 shows an upward trend from the census 2001 data.
Speaking on the occasion of [International Day of the Girl Child] in 2015, the [[Prime Minister of India|Prime Minister]], [[Narendra Modi]] had called for the eradication of [[female foeticide]] and invited suggestions from the citizens of India via the [[MyGov.in]] portal.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-pm-narendra-modi-invites-ideas-on-beti-bachao-beti-padhao-2025163|title=PM Narendra Modi invites ideas on "Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao"|date=11 October 2014|work=DNA India |accessdate=2016-06-12}}</ref>
The Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao (BBBP) [https://pradhanmantriyuvayojna.in/beti-bachao-beti-padhao-yojana/] scheme was launched on 22 January 2015 by Modi.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/nation/PM-to-Taunch-Beti-Bachao-Beti-Padhao-Programme-from-Haryana/2014/12/31/article2597270.ece|title=PM to Launch 'Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao' Programme from Haryana|website=Newindianexpress.com|accessdate=2016-06-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/pm-narendra-modi-to-launch-beti-bachao-beti-padhao-programme-from-haryana/articleshow/45707186.cms|title=PM Narendra Modi to launch 'Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao' programme from Haryana|work=The Economic Times|accessdate=2016-06-12}}</ref> It aims to address the issue of the declining child sex ratio image (CSR) and is a national initiative jointly run by the [[Ministry of Women and Child Development]], the [[Ministry of Health and Family Welfare]] and the [[Ministry of Human Resource Development]]. It initially focused multi-sector action in 100 districts throughout the country where there was a low CSR.
On 26 August 2016, Olympics 2016 bronze medallist [[Sakshi Malik]] was made brand ambassador for BBBP.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sportscafe.in/articles/wrestling/2016/aug/24/sakshi-malik-to-be-brand-ambassador-of-beti-bachao-beti-padhao-campaign-in-haryana|title=Sakshi Malik to be brand ambassador of 'Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao' campaign in Haryana|date=2016-08-24|access-date=2016-08-24}}</ref>
The hashtag #SelfieWithDaughter was promoted on social media in June 2015, which started when Sunil Jaglan the [[sarpanch]] of the village Bibipur, [[Jind district|Jind]] in [[Haryana]] took a [[selfie]] with his daughter Nandini and posted on Facebook on 9 June 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/how-pm-modis-beti-bachao-selfie-banao-campaign-became-a-rage-to-rewrite-gender-skewed-script-in-haryana/articleshow/47873120.cms |title=How PM Modi's Beti Bachao, Selfie Banao campaign became a rage to rewrite gender-skewed script in Haryana |publisher=''Economic Times'' |date=30 June 2015 |accessdate=1 July 2015 |author=Mohan, Rohini}}</ref> The hashtag garnered worldwide fame.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ndtv.com/india-news/selfiewithdaughter-trends-worldwide-after-pm-modis-mann-ki-appeal-776114 |title=#SelfieWithDaughter Trends Worldwide After PM Modi's Mann ki Baat |author=Sanyal, Anindita |publisher=''NDTV'' |date=28 June 2015 |accessdate=1 July 2015}}</ref>
==Reasons for this initiative== {{further|Female foeticide in India}} [[Sex-selective abortion]] or female foeticide has led to a sharp drop in the ratio of girls born in contrast to boy infants in some states in India. Ultrasound technology has made it possible for pregnant women and their families to learn the gender of a foetus early in a pregnancy. Discrimination against girl infants, for several reasons, has combined with the technology to result in a rise in abortions of foetuses identified as female during ultrasonic testing.
The trend was first noticed when results of the 1991 national census were released, and it was confirmed to be a worsening problem when results of the 2001 national census were released. The reduction in the female population of certain Indian states continues to worsen, as results of the 2011 national census have shown. It has been observed that the trend is most pronounced in relatively prosperous regions of India.<ref>{{cite book|title=Selections from regional press, V|page=68}}</ref> The [[dowry system in India]] is often blamed; the expectation that a large [[dowry]] must be provided for daughters in order for them to marry is frequently cited as a major cause for the problem.<ref>{{cite web|last=Panwar|first=Preeti|title=Female foeticide: Death before birth|url=http://bankersadda.me/sukanya-thev-yojna-at-11-14-rate-of-interest/|publisher=Bankersadda|accessdate=September 27, 2012|date=June 29, 2012}}</ref> Pressure for parents to provide large dowries for their daughters is most intense in prosperous states where high standards of living, and modern consumerism, are more prevalent in Indian society.
Rates of [[female foeticide]] in [[Madhya Pradesh]] are increasing; the rate of live births was 932 girls per 1000 boys in 2001, which dropped to 918 by 2011. It is expected that if this trend continues, by 2021 the number of girls will drop below 900 per 1000 boys.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gupta|first=Suchandana|title=Skewed sex ratio: MP launches 'Beti Bachao Abhiyan'|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Skewed-sex-ratio-MP-launches-Beti-Bachao-Abhiyan/articleshow/10212751.cms|accessdate=September 27, 2012|newspaper=Times of India|date=October 3, 2011}}</ref>
==Strategies used== Strategies employed to successfully carry out the scheme are: *Implement a sustained social mobilization and communication campaign to create equal value for the girl child and promote her education. *Place the issue of decline in child sex ratio/sex ratio at birth in public discourse, improvement of which would be an indicator for good governance. *Focus on gender critical districts and cities.
==Support== The [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] has formed a National Executive Committee to promote Beti Bachao Beti Padhao (BBBP) across the country. The committee is organising a number of programs to promote "Save Girl Child" and "to Educate Girl Child" since January 2015. Dr. Rajendra Phadke is the National Convener of BBBP Abhiyan.{{citation needed|date=October 2018}}
The Beti Bachao campaign is also supported by the [[Indian Medical Association]].<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Journal of the Indian Medical Association|year=2007|volume=105|issue=7-12|page=711|title=Indian Medical Association|publisher=Indian Medical Association}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name="Beti_bachao_beti_padhao_campaign_24072014">{{cite web|url=http://wcd.nic.in/tender/Beti_bachao_beti_padhao_campaign_24072014.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=5 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141105190442/http://wcd.nic.in/tender/Beti_bachao_beti_padhao_campaign_24072014.pdf |archivedate=5 November 2014 }}</ref> }}
{{Government Schemes in India}}

revision.text:
{{Underlinked|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox video game | title = Chemicus | released = 2001 }}
'''''Chemicus: Journey to the Other Side''''' is a 2001 educational adventure game by HEUREKA-Klett Softwareverlag as part of Tivola's "Quest for Knowledge" series. A sequel named '''''Chemicus II: Die versunkene Stadt''''' was released in 2002. The game was originally released in Germany.
== Gameplay == The first-person game has gameplay similar to ''Myst'' and ''Riven.''
== Plot == The player is a friend of Richard, a chemistry lover who is falsely accused of stealing a treaured item from the land of Chemicus after he arrives there in a portal. It is the player's job to rescue him.
The game has no death states.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407092141/http://www.uhs-hints.com/articles/reviews/chemicus.php|title=UHS: Chemicus Review|date=2016-04-07|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref>
== Critical reception == Eblong likened the game's puzzle design to games such as ''Zork Grand Inquisitor'', ''Myst'', and ''Traitors Gate'' though noted that puzzles are completed by doing chemistry experiments rather than using spells, in-universe mythology or technological gizmos respectively.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.eblong.com/zarf/gamerev/chemicus.html|title=Review: Chemicus|website=www.eblong.com|access-date=2017-12-23}}</ref> Metzomagic praised the game's graphics and musical score, and deemed it harder than its sister games [[Physicus]] and [[Bioscopia]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.metzomagic.com/showArticle.php?index=520|title=Chemicus Review by metzomagic.com|website=www.metzomagic.com|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> Adventure Gamers thought the concept was admirable and was interesting in playing the sequel.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041104191958/http://www.adventuregamers.com:80/display.php?id=224|title=Chemicus {{!}} Adventure Gamers|date=2004-11-04|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref>
Adventure Archiv thought the puzzles were fastidiously designed and that chemistry concepts were seamlessly integrated into the gameplay.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160311070649/http://adventurearchiv.de/c/chemicusreviewen.htm|title=Chemicus - Review english|date=2016-03-11|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> Gameboomers gave the game very high praise and was excited to try the other two games in the series,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160330111618/http://www.gameboomers.com/reviews/Cc/Chemicusbysyd.htm|title=Chemicus review by syd|date=2016-03-30|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> and Mr Bills Adventure Land went away with a similar impression.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160322024130/http://mrbillsadventureland.com/reviews/c-d/chemicusR/chemicusR.htm|title=Chemicus Review - Mr. Bill's Adventureland|date=2016-03-22|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> Tap Repeatedly highly recommended the game as a chemistry learning tool for children.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tap-repeatedly.com/Reviews/Chemicus/Chemicus.shtml|title=Four Fat Chicks -- Chemicus Review|website=www.tap-repeatedly.com|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> The AV Vault gave the game high praise, and noted that it managed to overcome the negative stigma around educational games as having "terrible graphics, shallow stories, little replay value, and shoddy production values".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060504114127/http://avault.com:80/reviews/review_temp.asp?game=chemi|title=AVault {{!}} PC {{!}} Chemicus: Journey to the Other Side Review|date=2006-05-04|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060528021804/http://avault.com:80/reviews/review_temp.asp?game=chemi&page=2|title=AVault {{!}} PC {{!}} Chemicus: Journey to the Other Side Review|date=2006-05-28|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041121141525/http://www.avault.com:80/reviews/review_temp.asp?game=chemi&page=3|title=AVault {{!}} PC {{!}} Chemicus: Journey to the Other Side Review|date=2004-11-21|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref>
Just Adventure noted that while there was an overarching goal, there was no plot-related logical reasoning given for the player to complete each individual puzzle, beside the fact that they can't progress to different areas until they do.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://justadventure.com/2013-05-20-21-09-14/1099-chemicus|title=Throwback Thursday: Chemicus|last=Tait|first=Alexander|website=justadventure.com|language=en|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> Similarly, Adventure Gamers thought the game could have been served better by having a juicier story that matched its intriguing world and puzzles.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://adventuregamers.com/articles/view/17597|title=Chemicus Review|website=Adventure Gamers|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> GameSpy offered a mixed review, but ultimately gave it a 1 star rating.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150908080721/http://pc.gamespy.com/pc/chemicus/5669p1.html|title=GameSpy: Chemicus - Page 1|date=2015-09-08|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> Mystery Manor wrote that the addition of a narrator would have sharply improved the game.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160805000429/http://mysterymanor.net/reviewchemicus.htm|title=Mystery Manor Chemicus Review|date=2016-08-05|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref>
AdventureTreff thought that Chemicus 2 worked well as a sequel, despite its limited budget.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050227220905/http://www.adventure-treff.de/artikel/tests/chemicus2.php|title=Adventure-Treff|date=2005-02-27|access-date=2017-12-23}}</ref>
=== Awards and nominations === * 2002 Comenius medal (won)<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.mediengewalt.de/spiele/beste-lernspiele-kinder-12-jahre.shtml|title=Beste Lernspiele für Kinder ab 12 Jahre (und andere Altersgruppen)|website=www.mediengewalt.de|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> * 2002 Giga Mouse - 6 mice (nominated)<ref name=":0" /> * 2002 Padi Seal of Approval<ref name=":0" /> * 2002 6 Buffalo at Edut@in-Preis<ref name=":0" />
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:2001 video games]] [[Category:Adventure games]] [[Category:Educational video games]] [[Category:MacOS games]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Germany]]

{{multiple issues| {{update|2011 ranking|date=July 2011}} {{more citations needed|date=September 2013}} }} The '''Chinese university ranking''' is a ranking of universities in mainland China by Netbig, an internet company focused on higher education, founded by Jiang Jining, who graduated from University of Science and Technology of China. The ranking is conducted annually since 1999, and is generally released in July, around the time of college entrance examination. This ranking, however, has ceased to publish newer versions since 2013.[http://www.netbig.com/ Official site displaying only the 2013 version] == Ranking methods == There are seven different ranking systems in Chinese university ranking (Netbig).{{cite web | title = 2013中国大学排名,2013大学排名,中国大学排行榜,综合指标排行 网大,网大-教育机构的价值发现者netbig.com！ |url=http://rank2013.netbig.com | accessdate = {{date|23 mar 2013}} }} The first ranking system is "comprehensive(overall) ranking", which is based on 2~7th ranking system. The second ranking system is based on "reputation". The third ranking system is based on “academic resources”. The fourth ranking system is based on "academic achievement". The fifth ranking system is based on "student ability". The sixth ranking system is based on "professor honor" The seventh ranking system is based on "reserve fund". ==Criticism== After its first release Netbig was sued by a [[Renmin University of China]] alumnus for committing libel to his Alma mater, by ranking the school 25th when it has the best law school in China. An official from the Chinese Ministry of Education commented on the ranking as being "baseless" and "completely without scientific studies."{{cite web | url=http://edu.sina.com.cn/edu/2000-08-17/10240.shtml | title=高校排行榜又引风波 人大毕业生状告网大 | accessdate=2014-03-13}}{{cite web | url=http://tech.sina.com.cn/internet/china/2000-07-10/30271.shtml | title=不满母校排名低 人大学子告"网大" | accessdate=2014-03-13}} Some also argued that Netbig did not but should have considered employment data in ranking the universities.[http://edu.sina.com.cn/gaokao/2011-06-07/2056299478.shtml 为什么网大不把就业率作为指标] == Top 10 Universities == The rank started in 1999 and ceased in 2013. ===1999=== 1. Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics ==See also== * [[University rankings in China]] * [[List of universities in China]] * [[Chinese university ranking (Chinese Academy of Management Science)]] * [[Chinese university ranking of billionaire alumni]] * [[Project 211]] * [[Project 985]] * [[863 Program]] * [[College and university rankings]] * [[Academic Ranking of World Universities]], by [[Shanghai Jiao Tong University]]’s Institute of Higher Education. * [[THES - QS World University Rankings]], by [[Times Higher Education|Times Higher Education (THE)]] and [[Quacquarelli Symonds]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == *http://www.netbig.com *http://rank.netbig.com {{Universities of China}} {{University ranking systems}} {{Education of the People's Republic of China}} [[Category:University and college rankings]] [[Category:Science and technology in the People's Republic of China]] [[Category:Universities in China]] [[Category:Higher education in China]]

{{Multiple issues| {{one source|date=June 2011}} {{COI|date=June 2011}} {{Underlinked|date=January 2015}} }}
The '''College of Chemical Sciences''' is an institute in [[Sri Lanka]]. It was established 25 January 2001 during the Diamond Jubilee celebration of the [[Institute of Chemistry Ceylon]].
As per by law 15 of the Institute of Chemistry Ceylon, the College of Chemical Sciences was established to conduct all the educational and training activities of the Institute. A Statutory Committee known as the Academic Board of the College of Chemical Sciences is appointed annually to promote, conduct and co-ordinate all the education, training and academic affairs of the College of Chemical Sciences. All the formal educational programmes are the immediate responsibility of this Board which is headed by the Chairman and includes, Deputy Chairman, Secretary for Educational Affairs, Assistant Secretary and eleven other elected members. Additionally, the President of the Institute, one of the Honorary Joint Secretaries of the Institute, the Chairman of the Admissions & Ethical Practices Committee of the Institute and the Institute’s Honorary Treasurer are ''ex officio'' members of the Academic Board.
The Chief Executive Officer of the Board is the Dean appointed by the Council Full-time Academic Staff Members and Teaching Assistants constitute the academic staff while the administrative staff is headed by the Registrar of the College. An Assistant Librarian is in charge of the Library. A number of other full-time non academic staff comprise the balance staff. A number of Visiting Academics & Teaching Assistants drawn from Universities, Research Institutes, and Service Organisations and well as the Private Sector carry out the day to day teaching activities of the College.
==Functions of the College== *to conduct post-secondary, Graduateship, Diploma and Certificate courses in the Chemical Sciences *to promote education in and application of Chemistry at levels *to initiate research activities in collaboration with Universities, Industry and foreign Institutions *to establish library facilities including database access and technology information *to conduct refresher/in-service/training courses for scientists and teachers *to assist industry in product development, problem solving, quality improvement and product diversification *to encourage staff exchange between the College and the Universities/ Research Institutes in Sri Lanka and overseas *to publish journals/monographs etc. to disseminate the latest know how in the Chemical Sciences *to take any measures that may be necessary for the attainment of the educational goals of the Institute
==List of College officers== *Hony. Dean, College of Chemical Sciences and Chairman - Academic Board : Prof J N Oleap Fernando, C.Chem., C.Sci., (Chartered Chemist) *Vice-Chairman, Academic Board : Prof. G M K B Gunaherath, C.Chem, (Chartered Chemist) *Secretary for Educational Affairs : Ms. P M Jayasinha, C.Chem, (Chartered Chemist) *Asst. Secretary for Educational Affairs : Ms. M N K de S Goonatillake, C.Chem, (Chartered Chemist) *Course Co-ordinator (Kandy) : Dr (Ms) A D L C Perera, C.Chem *Academic Laboratory Co-ordinator : Mr. M R M Haniffa, C.Chem, (Chartered Chemist) *Visiting Professor : Prof. S Sotheeswaran, D.Sc. (Hull), C.Chem, (Chartered Chemist) *Full Time Lecturers : Dr U S K Weliwegamage, C.Chem Dr. (Ms.) V M Thadhani *Registrar & Registrar/College of Chemical Sciences : Mr. N I N S Nadarasa, C.Chem, (Chartered Chemist) *Deputy Registrar/DLTC Co-ordinator : Mr J M Ranasinghe Banda, C.Chem, (Chartered Chemist) *Asst. Librarian/College of Chemical Sciences : Mr K G B Wimalasena
==External links== * [http://www.ichemc.edu.lk/ CCS official website]
