Total enrollment is about 480 students. There were ten sections (4 physical group and 6 biological group) in the year 2016/17. In 2009, LAC introduced GCE A Level course.[http://www.lac.edu.np/ LAC]. LAC. Retrieved on 23 October 2011. ==Little Angels' College of Management== The Little Angels' College of Management (LACM) was founded in 1999.[http://www.lacm.edu.np/ LACM]. LACM. Retrieved on 23 October 2011. LACM offers BBA, BBIS and BHTM degrees in affiliation with [[Kathmandu University]]. ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.la.edu.np/ Little Angels' Group] * [http://www.las.edu.np/ Little Angels' School] *[http://www.lac.edu.np/ Little Angels' College] *[http://www.lacm.edu.np/ Little Angels' College of Management] {{DEFAULTSORT:Little Angels School}} [[Category:Schools in Nepal]] [[Category:Lalitpur District, Nepal]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1981]] [[Category:Education in Nepal]]

{{Infobox writer | name = Max Hardberger | image =http://www.maxhardberger.com/images/photos/hardberger_beach.jpg | imagesize =200px | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = Florian Max Hardberger | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1948|11|19}} | birth_place = [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana]],
United States | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Novelist, Ship Captain, Ship Recovery Specialist, Maritime Lawyer | nationality = United States | period = | genre = [[nautical fiction|sea stories]], [[Adventure novel|Adventure]], [[Hardboiled]], [[Crime Fiction]] | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | influences = [[C.S. Forester]], [[Raymond Chandler]], [[Dashiell Hammett]], [[Ross Macdonald]], [[Robert Towne]], [[James M. Cain]], [[Frederick Exley]], [[Norman Spinrad]] | influenced = | signature = }} '''Florian Max Hardberger''' (born November 19, 1948)[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2424117/bio ''Internet Movie Database'' – Max Hardberger] is an American adventurer, [[Captain (nautical)|ship captain]], [[aviator]], ship recovery specialist, [[admiralty law]]yer and author of [[Sea story|maritime fiction]] and non-fiction adventures. == Education == Hardberger received his high school degree in 1966 from the [[Castle Heights Military Academy]] in Lebanon, Tennessee. He became a [[Private Pilot License|licensed aircraft pilot]] at the age of 16 while at Castle Heights.Rivault, Mike, [http://www.maxhardberger.com/pdf/UNO_Alumni_Magazine_Fall_2007.pdf "Freighter Repo Man"], ''University of New Orleans Alumni Magazine'', Fall 2007 Hardberger attended college at [[Nicholls State|Nicholls State University]] in Thibodaux, Louisiana then transferred to the [[University of New Orleans]] for another two years of study. In 1969 he graduated early with a BA in English. During college, Hardberger became a [[Scuba diving|SCUBA diver]], skilled sailor and [[Navigation|navigator]]. After college, Hardberger attended the Program in Creative Writing at the [[University of Iowa]] (commonly known as the "[[Iowa Writer's Workshop|Iowa Writers' Workshop]]"), where in 1972 he received a [[Master of Fine Arts]] degree in Fiction and Poetry.Schoon, Amy, [http://www.maxhardberger.com/pdf/Iowa_Alumni_Magazine_Feb_2008.pdf "The Good Pirate"], ''University of Iowa Alumni Magazine'', February 2008 In 1998, Hardberger earned a ''Juris Doctor'' degree from [[Northwestern California University School of Law]] in Sacramento, California, and was admitted to the [[State Bar of California]].[http://www.nwculaw.edu/cgi-bin/nwcu/notable_alumni.html ''Northwestern California University School of Law'' – Notable Alumni] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100507113710/http://www.nwculaw.edu/cgi-bin/nwcu/notable_alumni.html |date=2010-05-07 }} == Literary career == Hardberger's first book was ''Deadweight: Owning the Ocean Freighter'' (1994),[http://www.wikireadia.org/search-books-by-isbn.php?searchstr=0964043300&searchby=ISBN&action=Search WikiReadia – ''Deadweight: Owning the Ocean Freighter''] a textbook on ship ownership. He followed ''Deadweight'' with his first novel, ''Freighter Captain'' (1998),[http://www.wikireadia.org/search-books-by-isbn.php?searchstr=0964043378&searchby=ISBN&action=Search WikiReadia – ''Freighter Captain''] a semi-autobiographical account of his adventures as a ship captain in the Caribbean. Hardberger then moved from maritime subjects to a [[Crime fiction|murder mystery]] with his 1999 novel, ''The Jumping-Off Place,''[http://www.wikireadia.org/search-books-by-isbn.php?searchstr=096404336X&searchby=ISBN&action=Search WikiReadia – ''The Jumping-Off Place''] which was a tribute to the [[hardboiled]] detective novels of [[Raymond Chandler]] and [[Dashiell Hammett]]. On April 6, 2010, Hardberger's auto-biography about his ship recovery adventures was published by the [[Broadway Books]] imprint of [[Random House]], entitled ''SEIZED! A Sea Captain's Adventures Battling Scoundrels and Pirates While Recovering Stolen Ships in the World's Most Troubled Waters.''Hardberger, Max, [http://www.randomhouse.com/catalog/display.pperl?isbn=9780767931380&ref=rec&name=search ''Seized: A Sea Captain's Adventures Battling Scoundrels and Pirates While Recovering Stolen Ships in the World's Most Troubled Waters''], Broadway Books, 2010 A paperback edition of SEIZED for the [[British Commonwealth]] market will be released by Nicholas Brealey Publishing on June 24, 2010.[http://www.nicholasbrealey.com/uk/pc/viewPrd.asp?idcategory=93&idproduct=278 Nicholas Brealey Publishing Website – ''Seized'' Page] As a devotee of the [[hardboiled]] school of fiction, Hardberger's writing style offers gritty realism. Like his life, many of Hardberger's books are set in the seedy world of international business. His protagonists are often like himself, savvy, sardonic, and capable of violent action, and his villains are drawn from the panoply of miscreants he's met as a ship captain and maritime lawyer. Hardberger's stories are fact-based, real-world adventures from the underbelly of world commerce. ==Professional career== ===Teaching English and playing music – 1969 to 1976=== After college, Hardberger started his professional career with a short stint teaching English at [[Mandeville High School]] in Louisiana. Hardberger then worked as a newspaper reporter for the Houma Daily Guide in [[Houma, Louisiana]]. He left the newspaper to explore Mexico in an old school bus before returning to the United States to attend graduate school. After he received his [[Master of Fine Arts|MFA degree]] in 1972, Hardberger taught English at All Saints Episcopal School in [[Vicksburg, Mississippi]]. He left teaching to work as a drummer in various [[blues]] bands on the [[Chitlin Circuit]].''Seized'' (2010), p. 43 ===Oilfield worker and pilot – 1977 to 1985=== In 1977, Hardberger returned home to Louisiana to work as a deckhand and then as a mate on the [[Platform supply vessel|oilfield supply vessel]] ''Magcobar Mercury'' in the Gulf of Mexico. After he earned a captain's license, Hardberger's employer sent him to the Dresser-Magcobar Drilling Fluids School in Houston to learn how to become a [[Mud engineer|drilling fluids engineer]], also known as a "mud man." Hardberger initially worked in oilfields off the Louisiana and Mississippi [[Gulf Coast of the United States|Gulf Coast]] and then worked as a [[Mud engineer|drilling fluids consultant]] in Guatemala during the [[Guatemalan Civil War]]. Between oilfield hitches, Hardberger continued his flying lessons, earning [[Commercial Pilot License|commercial]] and [[flight instructor]] licenses, and took a wide variety of flying jobs, including towing banners, [[crop dusting|dusting crops]], doing nightly check runs for banks and transporting dead bodies for mortuaries.''Seized'' (2010), p. 44 Hardberger also delivered aircraft to Central America. Hardberger returned to the classroom for the 1984–85 school year, when he taught English and world history at [[Pope John Paul II High School (Slidell, Louisiana)]].''Seized'' (2010), p. 63 Hardberger briefly returned to the oilfields of Guatemala in 1985, then began [[crop dusting]] on a full-time basis in [[Breaux Bridge]], Louisiana. At the end of the 1986 [[crop dusting]] season, Hardberger traveled to Miami, Florida to search for new work.''Seized'' (2010), p. 64 ===Ship captain – 1986 to 1990=== When [[Jean-Claude Duvalier|Jean-Claude "Baby Doc" Duvalier]] was overthrown as the ruler of Haiti in 1986, trade opened up between the United States and Haiti. The [[Miami River (Florida)|Miami River]] was the loading port for many small freighters in the Haitian trade. After Hardberger left [[crop dusting]], he searched for and soon found work on the [[Miami River (Florida)|Miami River]] as the captain of a small freighter engaged in that trade.''Seized'' (2010), p. 66 Among his commands was the ''Erika'', a small freighter which transported cargoes throughout the Caribbean. Hardberger's voyages on the ''Erika'' were the basis of his 1998 semi-autobiographical novel, ''Freighter Captain''.Weikel, Dan, [http://www.maxhardberger.com/pdf/Los_Angeles_Times_March_1_2007.pdf "He's His Own Port Authority"], ''Los Angeles Times'', March 1, 2007 ===Recovering vessels – 1990 to present=== Hardberger left the ''Erika'' to work for a Miami-based ship owner, MorganPrice & Co.,[http://www.morganpriceco.com/HomeEnglish.htm MorganPrice & Co. Website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100309013333/http://www.morganpriceco.com/HomeEnglish.htm |date=2010-03-09 }} as port captain responsible for overseeing port calls by the company's ships. During this period, a MorganPrice freighter, the ''Patric M'', was seized by a shipper in [[Puerto Cabello]], Venezuela. This action required Hardberger to sail the vessel out of port under the cover of night and without a clearance, in violation of Venezuelan law.Author Unknown, [http://www.maxhardberger.com/pdf/Florida_Shipper_Magazine_July_1990.pdf "Commando Action Saves Ship"], ''Florida Shipper Magazine'', July 16, 1990 This operation was Hardberger's first vessel "extraction" and is detailed in his autobiography, ''Seized''.''Seized'' (2010), pp. 15–61 Hardberger left MorganPrice in 1990 to form his own marine consultancy business in Louisiana. He was periodically retained by shipowners to extract their vessels from lawless ports without a clearance from local authorities. In 1998, following his admission to the California Bar, Hardberger began to practice maritime law alongside his marine consultancy and vessel extraction business. In 2002, Hardberger formed the ship repossession company Vessel Extractions, LLC ("VessEx") to extract vessels that have been illegitimately detained or seized in foreign countries. In 2004, Hardberger was featured in [[The Learning Channel]] series, ''Repo Men: Stealing for a Living'', in a segment entitled "Repo Adventurer,"documenting his extraction of a 10,000-ton freighter from Haiti during the [[2004 Haiti rebellion|2004 rebellion]] and his delivery of the vessel to her mortgagee in the Bahamas.Watson, Will, [http://www.maxhardberger.com/pdf/Fairplay_Magazine_April_26_2007.pdf "Just What the Witch Doctor Ordered"], ''Fairplay International Shipping Weekly'', April 26, 2007 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.maxhardberger.com/ Max Hardberger's Official Website] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hardberger, Max}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American non-fiction writers]] [[Category:California lawyers]] [[Category:Iowa Writers' Workshop alumni]] [[Category:Maritime writers]] [[Category:Nicholls State University alumni]] [[Category:Writers from Baton Rouge, Louisiana]] [[Category:University of New Orleans alumni]]

[[File:MCS-Logo.JPG|200px|right|Logo of the Medieval Chronicle Society]] The '''Medieval Chronicle Society''' is an international and interdisciplinary organization founded to facilitate the work of scholars interested in medieval [[annals]] and [[chronicle]]s, or more generally medieval [[historiography]].<ref>Albrecht Classen, ''Handbook of Medieval Studies'', 2010, p.1719.</ref><ref>For press reports on the Society see for example ''Frankfurter Allgemeine Sonntagzeitung'', 22 May 2011, p.63.</ref> It was founded in 1999 and in February 2011 had 380 members.
==Aims and history== Annals and chronicles were the main genres of historical writing in the [[Middle Ages]]. Consequently, they have always been of great importance to [[historians]]. The extent to which they are also of interest to students of [[medieval literature]] or of [[historical linguistics]] was only fully realised in the latter part of the 20th century. Since many chronicles are illustrated, they are also a fruitful object of study for [[art history|art historians]]. It was the desire for a forum in which these disciplines could operate together that led to the foundation of the society.
The history of the society began with a series of triennial conferences initially in [[Utrecht (city)|Utrecht]], but later moving from place to place. These early conferences were hosted by Erik Kooper (English studies, Utrecht). It was at the second of these conferences, in 1999, that the society was formally founded.
The society maintains a website financed by the University of Liverpool, and publishes a regular newsletter with information on recent publications in the chronicles field.
==Journal ''The Medieval Chronicle''== [[File:MedievalChronicle4.jpg|150px|right|The journal ''The Medieval Chronicle'']] Volumes of proceedings of the first three conferences were published by Rodopi.<ref>''The Medieval Chronicle'' volumes 1–3, [[Rodopi (publisher)|Rodopi]], 1999–2004.</ref> When the society was founded, this triennial publication was transformed into a yearbook, now the peer-reviewed journal ''The Medieval Chronicle''.<ref>''The Medieval Chronicle'' volumes 4– , [[Rodopi (publisher)|Rodopi]], 2006– , ISSN 1567-2336.</ref>
The journal is trilingual, with articles in English, French and German. As well as the proceedings of the society's conferences, and also of the Cambridge Chronicle Symposium, the journal includes research submitted independently of the conferences. A number of text editions of chronicles have also been published here.
==Conferences== Conferences to date: #1996 Utrecht ([[Driebergen-Rijsenburg|Driebergen]]) #1999 Utrecht (Driebergen) <ref>Report on the second Driebergen conference, ''[http://www.seiten.faz-archiv.de/faz/19990804/fnuw19990804124413.html Frankfürter Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung]'' 4 August 1999.</ref> #2002 Utrecht ([[Doorn]]) #2005 [[Reading, Berkshire|Reading]] #2008 [[Belfast]] #2011 [[Pécs]] <ref>[http://www.pte.hu/hirek/2358 Report on the Pécs conference on Hungarian television]</ref> #2014 [[Liverpool]] #2017 [[Lisbon]] #2020 (planned) [[Poznań]]
==Projects== A number of interdisciplinary projects have been inspired by the society, including ''Repertorium Chronicarum'' an on-line database of Latin chronicle manuscripts maintained by Dan Embree on the website of Mississippi State university.<ref>Online [http://www.chronica.msstate.edu/chronica/ here]</ref>
[[File:EMC cover.jpg|150px|right|Cover of the EMC]] A major project of the society was the ''Encyclopedia of the Medieval Chronicle'' published in Leiden by [[Brill Publishers|Brill]].<ref>Graeme Dunphy. ''Encyclopedia of the Medieval Chronicle''. Leiden: Brill. 2009. {{ISBN|90-04-18464-3}}. See page viii for the link to the Chronicle Society. Reviews: ''[https://scholarworks.iu.edu/dspace/handle/2022/13447 The Medieval Review] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121003013527/https://scholarworks.iu.edu/dspace/handle/2022/13447 |date=2012-10-03 }}'' August 2010; ''[http://www.faz.net/aktuell/feuilleton/buecher/rezensionen/sachbuch/dunphy-encyclopedia-of-the-medieval-chronicle-nur-englaender-wissen-artus-zu-begraben-11115139.html Frankfürter Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung]'' 3 August 2011; ''Aetas'' 20 (2011), 208-11; ''[http://www.iaslonline.de/index.php?vorgang_id=3488 IASL-Online]''; ''Modern Language Review'' 107 (2012), 1226-28; ''[http://www.perspectivia.net/content/publikationen/francia/francia-recensio/2012-3/MA/dunphy_decazanove Francia-Recensio]'', 2012; ''Revue des Etudes Sud-Est Européennes / Journal of South-East European Studies'', 50 (2012), 365-366; ''[http://hsozkult.geschichte.hu-berlin.de/rezensionen/2012-4-068 H-Soz-u-Kult]'', 2012; ''Mediaevistik'', 24 (2012), 381-383; ''Das Mittelalter'', 17 (2012), 153-154; ''Historische Zeitschrift'', 296 (2013), 174-175; ''[http://www.sehepunkte.de/2013/06/19970.html sehepunkte]'', 13 (2013), Nr. 6. </ref> The ''EMC'' contains around 2500 usually quite short articles on individual authors or on anonymous works. A majority of these are from Western Christendom, but there are also entries on Slavic, Byzantine, Syriac, Islamic and Jewish chronicles. These give information on the date, language, form and manuscript tradition, and discuss issues which have been highlighted in recent scholarship. There are also about 60 longer "thematic" articles on particular aspects of chronicles. The two-volume paper edition appeared in 2010 and runs to around 1830 pages, with about 60 black-and-white full-page illustrations. About 450 scholars collaborated in writing it. An electronic edition with additional articles appeared in 2012; an update with significant expansions appeared in 2016.
==See also== *[[List of historical societies]] *[[List of literary societies]] *[[Rolls Series]] *[[Text publication society]]

[[File:Meyrianne Héglon en costume de scène btv1b8420920g.jpg|thumb|<center>Meyrianne Héglon in stage costume</center>]]
'''Marie-Antoinette Willemsen''' called '''Meyrianne Héglon''' (21 June 1867 – 11 January 1942) was a Belgian lyric artist of Danish origin. After her marriage to the composer [[Xavier Leroux]], she was known as Madame '''Héglon-Leroux'''.
== Life == Born in Brussels, Héglon studied with [[Marie Sax]] and Barthot, Tequi and [[Louis-Henri Obin]] and continued her studies with [[Rosine Laborde]].<ref name="SOPER">{{en icon}} Richard T. Soper, ''Belgian Opera Houses and Singers'' (Reprint Company 1999), p.265-266. {{ISBN|9780871525161}}</ref> She made her debut at the [[Paris Opera]] in November 1890, as Maddalena in ''[[Rigoletto]]''.
She sang at [[La Monnaie]] in 1894-1895 and later in 1901-1902. She performed as a guest artist in [[Ghent]] in 1898-1899.
Héglon, frequently appeared at the [[Paris Opera]] from 1897 to 1907. On April 7, 1898 at the Paris Opera, she sang at the world premiere of ''[[Quattro pezzi sacri|Tre pezzi sacri]]''<ref group="note">at the time composed of three parts</ref> by [[Verdi]], with her and [[Marie Delna]] as [[mezzo-soprano]]s and Aino Acté and [[Louise Grandjean]] as [[soprano]]s, as part of the concerts of the [[Orchestre de la Société des concerts du Conservatoire]], conducted by [[Paul Taffanel]]. She sang the role of Omphale in the première of Leroux's ''[[Astarté (opera)|Astarté]]'' in 1901<ref>{{Cite news|language= fr|author1=[[Paul Milliet]]|title=Première représentation d'Astarté|journal=Le Monde artiste|volume=|issue=7|date=17 February 1901|pages=2|issn=|url=https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5454043b/f10.image|accessdate= 16 November 2018}}.</ref> with [[Louise Grandjean]], Albert Alvarez, [[Francisque Delmas]].<ref name="LYRICA">{{Cite news|language= fr|author1=Szifer|title=La mort de Mlle Louise Grandjean|journal=Lyrica|volume=|issue=2540|date= May 1934|pages=|issn=|url=https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5410879c/f4.item.r=%22Louise%20Grandjean%22|accessdate= 16 November 2018}}.</ref>
Héglon spent a large part of her career at the [[Opéra de Monte-Carlo]]. On October 4, 1898, she signed a contract for three performances of ''Amneris'', in Italian and four for the premiere of the title role of Isidore de Lara's ''[[Messaline]]''. Héglon received considerable support from [[Camille Saint-Saëns]] and sang in his ''[[Samson and Delilah (opera)|Delilah]]'' in 1904.<ref name="SOPER"/>
She appeared in 1898 in the role of Anne Boleyn in ''[[Henry VIII (opera)|Henry VIII]]'' at [[Covent Garden]] where she performed on July 13, 1899 in the title role of ''Messaline'' with Albert Alvarez in the role of Helion and [[Maurice Renaud]] in that of Harès. She also sang in the main operas of Belgium, ''[[Rigoletto (opera)|Rigoletto]]'' in 1904 at the Théâtre Royal [[Antwerp]]. At the [[Opéra-Comique]], she created the role of La Vougne in [[Alexandre Georges]]' ''Miarka'',<ref>[http://data.bnf.fr/14817098/alexandre_georges_miarka/ ''Miarka''] on [[BnF]]</ref> on November 7, 1905 and also did this premiere in London.
After her retirement from the stage, she taught singing and among her most notable students was the French soprano [[Ninon Vallin]].
On April 8, 1917, her husband Xavier Leroux directed his work ''[[Les cadeaux de Noël]]''. The participating artists, Monin, Stura, Vellini and Coste, were all students of Héglon. On April 6, 1918, another work by her husband was performed, ''1814''. For this performance, she came out of retirement to sing the role of The Mother.<ref name="SOPER"/>
She has made four rare recordings fo [[Gramophone Company]] in 1904. Her voice can be heard on the anthology album ''[[The Record of Singing#The Record of Singing Volume 1 (1899–1919)|The Record of Singing Volume I (1899-1919)]]''.
== Repertoire == *Cassandre ''[[Les Troyens]]'' *Uta ''[[Sigurd (opera)|Sigurd]]'' *Edwige ''[[William Tell (opera)|William Tell]]'' *Amneris ''[[Aida]]'' *Dalila ''[[Samson and Delilah (opera)|Samson and Delilah]]'' *Fricka ''[[Die Walküre]]'' *Yamina ''La Montagne Noire'' by [[Augusta Holmès]] *La Reine ''[[Hamlet (opera)|Hamlet]]'' *Anne ''[[Henry VIII (opera)|Henri VIII]]'' *Fides ''[[Le Prophète]]''
== Premieres == ; At the [[Opéra de Paris]] : * 1893: Schwertleite in ''[[Die Walküre]]'', 12 May * 1894: Myrtale in ''[[Thais (opera)|Thais]]'', 16 March * 1894: Ourvaci in ''Djelma'', 25 May * 1894: Emilia in ''[[Otello (Verdi)|Otello]]'', 10 Oct * 1895: Dara in ''La Montagne noire'', 8 February.<ref>{{Cite web|title=La Montagne-Noire: drame lyrique en quatre actes et cinq tableaux|url=https://bibliotheques-specialisees.paris.fr/ark:/73873/pf0000333030/v0001.simple.selectedTab=thumbnail|website=Bibliothèques spécialisées de la Ville de Paris|accessdate= 16 November 2018}}</ref> * 1898: Pyrrha de''La Burgonde'', 23 December * 1901: Omphale in Leroux's ''[[Astarté (opera)|Astarté]]'', February * 1901: Title role of ''[[Frédégonde]]'' * 1901: Livie in ''[[Les barbares]]'', 23 October * 1902: Erda in ''[[Siegfried (opera)|Siegfried]]'', 3 January.<ref>{{Cite news|language=fr|author1=[[Arthur Pougin]]|title=La première représentation de Siegfried à Paris|journal=Le Ménestrel|volume=|issue=3593|date=5 January 1902|pages=2|issn=|url=https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5782521d/f9.item.r=Siefried.zoom|accessdate = 16 November 2018}}.</ref> * Liba in ''La Cloche du Rhin''<ref>[http://data.bnf.fr/14813705/samuel_rousseau_la_cloche_du_rhin/ ''La Cloche du rhin''] on BnF</ref> * Title role of Haendel's ''[[Theodora (Handel)|Theodora]]''

page.title: New Partnership for Africa's Development E-School Program

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=February 2015}} The '''New Partnership for Africa's Development E-School Programme''' run by [[NEPAD]] aims to provide computers and internet access to all schools in [[Africa]] within 10 years, and also to set up health points to tie in with Nepad's [[E-Health]] program.
The project was launched in 2003 at the [[African Economic Summit]] in [[Durban]]. The aim is to cover all high schools within 5 years of the start of implementation and all primary schools within 10 years, a total of some 600,000 schools.
In June, 2005, at the [[World Economic Forum|World Economic Forum Africa Summit]] in [[Cape Town]], it was announced that the first school to benefit from the program would be [[Bugulumbya Secondary School]] in the village of [[Busobya]], [[Uganda]]. A consortium of companies led by [[Hewlett Packard]] is to equip the school in collaboration with the Ugandan government.
A demonstration project involving various private companies is planned to take place over 12-18 months in 16 countries including: [[Algeria]], [[Burkina Faso]], [[Cameroon]], [[Egypt]], [[Gabon]], [[Ghana]], [[Kenya]], [[Lesotho]], [[Mali]], [[Mauritius]], [[Mozambique]], [[Nigeria]], [[Rwanda]], [[Senegal]], [[South Africa]] and Uganda.
==External links== *[http://www.nepad.org/2005/news/wmview.php?ArtID=30 nepad.org] report *[http://www.itweb.co.za/sections/business/2005/0506011101.asp?S=All%20Africa%20News&A=AFN&O=SLF itweb.co.za] report *[http://www.miningweekly.co.za/min/essentials/careers/?show=68321 mininweekly.co.za]
[[Category:African Union]] [[Category:Education in Africa]] [[Category:New Partnership for Africa's Development]]
{{Africa-stub}}

{{Infobox book | name = Newton for Beginners | title_orig = | translator = | image = NewtonBeginners.jpg | caption = First edition cover | author = William Rankin | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | series = [[Introducing... book series|Introducing...]] | subject = [[Isaac Newton]]
[[Classical Physics]] | genre = | publisher = Icon Books (UK)
Totem Books (US) | release_date = 1993 | media_type = Print | pages = | isbn = 1863734953 | dewey = | congress = | oclc = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Newton for Beginners''''', republished as '''''Introducing Newton''''', is a 1993 [[graphic novel|graphic]] [[study guide]] to the [[Isaac Newton]] and [[classical physics]] written and illustrated by William Rankin. The volume, according to the publisher's website, "explains the extraordinary ideas of a man who [...] single-handedly made enormous advances in [[mathematics]], [[mechanics]] and [[optics]]," and, "was also a secret [[heretic]], a [[mysticism|mystic]] and an [[alchemist]]."{{cite web |title=Introducing Newton: A Graphic Guide |first= |last= |url=http://www.introducingbooks.com/title/introducing-newton/ |work=Icon Books |date= |accessdate=2017-01-20 }} "William Rankin," ''[[Public Understanding of Science]]'' reviewer Patrick Fullick confirms, "sets out to illuminate the man whose work laid the foundations of the physics of the last 350 years, and to place him and his work in the context of the times in which he lived."{{cite journal |last=Fullick |first=Patrick |date=1995 |title=Educating the new Aristotelians |url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1088/0963-6625/4/1/006 |journal=[[Public Understanding of Science]] |volume=4 |issue= |pages=77-84 |doi= |access-date=2017-01-15 }} ''[[New Scientist]]'' reviewer Roy Herbert adds that, "alongside theories of the Universe from ancient times, the book explains those originating since Isaac Newton, so placing him deftly in his scientific context."{{cite journal |last=Herbert |first=Roy |date=24 July 1993 |title=Paperbacks – Roy Herbert weighs up the lives of Isambard Kingdom Brunel and Isaac Newton, looks at left-handedness, sheep slayers and near death experiences, and ponders the mystery of speech |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg13918835-100/ |journal=[[New Scientist]] |volume= |issue=1883 |pages= |doi= |access-date=2017-01-15 }} ==Publication History== This volume was originally published in the UK by Icon Books in 1993 as ''Newton for Beginners'', and subsequently republished with different covers in different editions. Selected editions: *{{cite book|year=1993|title=Newton for Beginners|publisher=Icon Books|location=|page=|chapter=|isbn=1863734953}} *{{cite book|year=2000|title=Introducing Newton and Classical Physics|publisher=Icon Books|location=|page=|chapter=|isbn=1840461586}} *{{cite book|year=2007|title=Introducing Newton|publisher=Icon Books|location=|page=|chapter=|isbn=1840468424}} *{{cite book|year=2012|title=Introducing Newton: A Graphic Guide|publisher=Icon Books|location=|page=|chapter=|isbn=1848311761}} Related volumes in the series: *{{cite book|first1=Joseph|last1=Schwartz|first2=Michael|last2=McGuinness|year=1992|title=[[Einstein for Beginners]]|publisher=Icon Books|location=|page=|chapter=|isbn=1874166021}} *{{cite book|first1=Pirani|last1=Felix|first2=Roche|last2=Christina|year=1993|title=[[The Universe for Beginners]]|publisher=Icon Books|location=|page=|chapter=|isbn=1874166064}} *{{cite book|first1=J.P.|last1=McEvoy|first2=Oscar|last2=Zárate|year=1995|title=Stephen Hawking for Beginners|publisher=Icon Books|location=|page=|chapter=|isbn=}} *{{cite book|first1=J.P.|last1=McEvoy|first2=Oscar|last2=Zárate|year=1996|title=Quantum Theory for Beginners|publisher=Icon Books|location=|page=|chapter=|isbn=}} *{{cite book|first1=Craig|last1=Callender|first2=Ralph|last2=Edney|year=2001|title=Introducing Time|publisher=Icon Books|location=|page=|chapter=|isbn=}} *{{cite book|first1=Bruce|last1=Bassett|first2=Ralph|last2=Edney|year=2002|title=[[Introducing Relativity]]|publisher=Icon Books|location=|page=|chapter=|isbn=1840463724}} *{{cite book|first1=Brian|last1=Clegg|first2=Oliver|last2=Pugh|year=2012|title=Introducing Infinity|publisher=Icon Books|location=|page=|chapter=|isbn=}} *{{cite book|first1=Tom|last1=Whyntie|first2=Oliver|last2=Pugh|year=2013|title=Introducing Particle Physics|publisher=Icon Books|location=|page=|chapter=|isbn=}} ==Reception== "This book shares the general characteristics of the ''Beginners'' series with a large number of line drawings and cartoons with associated text and many asides," states Patrick Fullick, writing in ''[[Public Understanding of Science]]'', "for some readers the asides may seem idiosyncratic or even annoying." "Some may dislike the humour and bad puns that abound in this work," confirms Bill Palmer, writing in the ''Journal of the Science Teacher Association of the Northern Territory'', "but I suspect that those starting the study of Newton's life and work will appreciate this attempt to facilitate reading."{{cite journal |last=Palmer |first=Bill |date=1997 |title=Book review ''Newton for Beginners'' |url= |journal=Journal of the Science Teacher Association of the Northern Territory |volume=16 |issue=160-161 |pages= |doi= |access-date= }} "The book is well-grounded in recent historiography," and, "Rankin is clearly sympathetic towards his subject," states Fullick, "but inevitably Newton still comes over as one whose intellectual vanity was at times apt to overcome his self-control." Roy Herbert, writing in ''[[New Scientist]]'', confirms that despite being a colossus, "Many of his contemporaries saw him as something else and these bit players provide a background of 17th-century backbiting and squabbling (Newton took part) that is always fascinating." "Newton's story is told accurately and entertainingly," concludes Palmer. "It combines drawings with text and pulls off the difficult trick of imparting serious information while keeping the reader amused with jokes and irreverent asides," adds Herbert, "it is a technique that has strong appeal and so, even if you have misgivings about it, you are lured along the trail." "The communication of the idea that the great scientists of the past had their hopes and fears and that they had concerns other than the purely academic or professional is probably done as well pictorially as by other means," confirms Fullick. "Easily swallowed and," concludes Herbert, "retainable." ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Non-fiction graphic novels]] [[Category:Biographical comics]] [[Category:Comics based on real people]] [[Category:Popular science books]] [[Category:Educational comics]] [[Category:1993 in comics]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Isaac Newton]] [[Category:Comics set in the 17th century]] [[Category:Comics set in the United Kingdom]]

{{UPE|date=June 2018}} {{notability|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Nikki Sharp | image = N Sharp food shot.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1987|06|10|mf=yes}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | monuments = | residence = [[Los Angeles]], USA | nationality = | other_names = | ethnicity = <!-- Ethnicity should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = [[University of Northern Colorado]] | occupation = Author & Former-model | years_active = | known_for = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = [[Muriel Sharp]] (mother) | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | website = [http://www.nikkisharp.com/ nikkisharp.com] }}
'''Nikki Sharp''' (born June 10, 1987) is an American author, former-model , health and fitness<ref>{{cite web |url= http://vivaglammagazine.com/vegan-blueberry-cheesecake/ |title= Vegan Blueberry Cheesecake |work= Viva Glam Magazine |date= 2016-04-06 |accessdate=2018-03-03}}</ref> blogger.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/meal-prepping-is-blowing-up-2016-3?IR=T |title= The new healthy food trend is meal prepping, and it's blowing up on Instagram |work= Business Insider |date= 2016-03-01 |accessdate=2018-03-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.accessonline.com/articles/nikki-sharps-new-years-5-day-detox/ |title= Nikki Sharp's New Year's 5-Day Detox |work= Access Hollywood |date= 2016-01-04 |accessdate=2018-03-03}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Nikki Sharp was born in [[Boulder, Colorado]] in June 1987 to [[Muriel Sharp]] and Alec Sharp, both of whom are from London. Sharp’s mother, Muriel took part in the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles representing Team GB in the Road Racing cycling event.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://hipandhealthy.com/fitspiration-nikki-sharp/ |title= Fitspiration – Nikki Sharp! |work= Hip & Healthy |date= 2014-10-10 |accessdate=2018-03-03}}</ref> Sharp’s father Alec, was a software programmer who published a book called "Smalltalk by Example: The Developer's Guide”, which was released in 1997.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/66562.SmallTalk_by_Example |title= SmallTalk by Example: The Developer's Guide to VisualWorks, with Disk |work= Good Reads |accessdate=2018-03-12}}</ref> Sharp grew up in [[Boulder, Colorado]] where she attended the [[University of Colorado Boulder]] then transferred to the [[University of Northern Colorado]], where she graduated with honors with a degree in communications and minor in journalism in 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.thriveglobal.com/stories/24017-how-this-wellness-expert-rediscovered-her-passion |title= How This Wellness Expert Rediscovered Her Passion |work= Thrive Global Magazine |accessdate=2018-03-03}}</ref> After graduating Sharp moved to [[Shanghai]] for her first modelling contract.
==Career== ===Modelling=== Sharp began her career as an international model<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.bikiniluxe.com/blogs/fitness-blog/nikki-sharp |title= NIKKI SHARP GOES FROM MODEL TO INFLUENCER |work= Bikini Luxe |accessdate=2018-03-10}}</ref> after graduating from college. In mid-2008, relocated to Shanghai on a modeling contract. Over the next 4 years, Sharp was based in numerous cities such as Sydney, Seoul, Bangkok, Athens, London, New York and London. In 2017 Viva Glam named her as one of their top 20 models.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://vivaglammagazine.com/viva-glams-sexiest-top-20-nikki-sharp/ |title=VIVA GLAM SUPERMODELSAUGUST 29, 2017VIVA GLAM’s Sexiest Top 20 Nikki Sharp |work= Viva Glam Magazine |accessdate=2018-03-03}}</ref>
===The 5-Day Detox=== After moving back to London in 2012, she started her brand and created The 5-Day Detox that December.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.foxnews.com/health/2014/05/14/healthy-detox-in-just-five-days.html|title= days |work= Fox |date=2014-05-15 |accessdate=2018-03-08}}</ref> As her Instagram account grew, she was featured in the press as ‘Top Instagram Account to follow’ and ‘Top Fitness Accounts’.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.marieclaire.co.uk/life/health-fitness/6-fitness-accounts-to-follow-on-instagram-105317 |title= 6 Inspiring Fitness Accounts To Follow On Instagram |work= Marie Claire |date=2014-02-18 |accessdate=2018-03-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.hercampus.com/school/western/popular-health-fitness-icons-follow-inspiration |title= Popular Health & Fitness Icons to Follow for Inspiration |work= Her Campus Magazine |date=2017-01-10 |accessdate=2018-03-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://yogalifestyles.com/22-instagram-yogis-to-start-following/ |title= 22 Instagram Yogis You Need Start Following |work= Yoga Lifestyles |date=2016-04-22 |accessdate=2018-03-04}}</ref> Sharp developed and released her mobile app, The 5-Day Detox, in November 2015, where it topped the charts at #1 in six countries worldwide.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxla.com/good-day/good-day-la-experts-and-other-guests/nikki-sharp-real-food-detox-for-global-health-day |title= Nikki Sharp: Real food detox for Global Health Day |work= Fox |date=2016-06-09 |accessdate=2018-03-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://thenativesociety.com/nativeadmission/2016/4/12/nikki-sharp-wellness-expert-lifestyle-blogger-health-coach.html |title= NIKKI SHARP: WELLNESS EXPERT, LIFESTYLE BLOGGER & HEALTH COACH |work= The Native Society |date=2016-04-12 |accessdate=2018-03-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.thriveglobal.com/stories/24017-how-this-wellness-expert-rediscovered-her-passion |title= How This Wellness Expert Rediscovered Her Passion |work= Thrive Magazine |date=2018-02-21 |accessdate=2018-03-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.popsugar.co.uk/fitness/Tip-Stop-Emotional-Eating-40947827 |title= A Simple but Powerful Trick to Stop Emotional Eating |work= Pop Sugar |date= 2016-11-04 |accessdate=2018-03-10}}</ref>
===Television=== Sharp occasionally does live Television features on health & wellness.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.hallmarkchannel.com/home-and-family/wednesday-march-30th-2016 |title= WEDNESDAY, MARCH 30TH, 2016 |work= Hallmark Channel |accessdate=2018-03-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/access-hollywood-live/episode-29820959/339804/ |title= Access Hollywood Live |work= TV Guide |accessdate=2018-03-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.leadwithloveaspen.org/nikki-sharp-2017/ |title= FEATURED SPEAKER NIKKI SHARP |work= Lead With Love |accessdate=2018-03-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5990100/ |title= Live with Nikki Sharp |work= IMDB |accessdate=2018-03-05}}</ref>
==Bibliography== Sharp is the author of The 5-Day Real Food Detox,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/253593/the-5-day-real-food-detox-by-nikki-sharp/9781101886922/ |title= The 5-Day Real Food Detox |work= Penguin Random House |accessdate=2018-03-04}}</ref> published by [[Random House]] in 2016 which endorses a plant-based cleanse that does not involve juicing or smoothies.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/14104738.Nikki_Sharp |title= Nikki Sharp |work= Good Reads |accessdate=2018-03-05}}</ref> Sharp’s latest book, is titled "Meal Prep Your Way to Weight Loss” (released in 2018).<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.booksforbetterliving.com/detox-preparation-plan/ |title= The Detox Preparation Plan |work= Books for better Living |date= 2017-08-05 |accessdate=2018-03-05}}</ref>
==Website==
Nikki Sharp's website URL is http://www.nikkisharp.com
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox Magazine | image_file = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = |editor = |frequency = Monthly |category = |company = |publisher = Department of Education, Western Australia |founded = 1926 |lastdate = 1946 |country = Australia |based = [[Perth]] |language = |website = |issn = }} '''''Our Rural Magazine''''' was a monthly magazine produced between 1926 and 1946 by the [[Schools of Isolated and Distance Education|WA Correspondence School]]{{cite web|url=http://www.side.wa.edu.au/about/welcome/side-heritage.html|title=Heritage, The SIDE Story|publisher=Schools of Isolated and Distance Education WA|accessdate=9 March 2014}} of the [[Education Department of Western Australia]] for school children who were located in isolated circumstances.Western Australia. Education Dept. 1926 Our rural magazine. Vol. 1, no. 1 (1926) - v. 14, no. 11 (1939) for National Library of Australia holdings - [[Battye Library]] has minimal description and claims 1946 as final year http://henrietta.liswa.wa.gov.au/record=b1845381~S2 In the inter-war period, many isolated rural localities did not have primary schools, and the students were required to have their education by correspondence. The magazine was based in Perth.{{cite web|title=Our rural magazine|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/12937894?selectedversion=NBD5433786|work=National Library of Australia|accessdate=11 February 2017}} It was operated by the Education Department, with writers such as James PollardPollard also was writing school texts in the same era - see - Pollard, James (1936). In Nature's story book : nature stories at school, in town, and in bushland : a reader for classes III & IV. E.B. Bayliss Print, Perth, W.A and [[John K. Ewers]]."OUR RURAL MAGAZINE.". (25 March 1931). The West Australian (Perth, WA : 1879-1954), p. 13. Retrieved 16 July 2011, from http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article32507277 Also heads of various institutions wrote on topics related to their position - in the September 1933 edition - the Government Botanist [[C.A.Gardner]] writes, as well as the curator of the Museum [[Ludwig Glauert]] conducts a correspondence column."OUR RURAL MAGAZINE.". (2 October 1933). The West Australian (Perth, WA : 1879-1954), p. 14. Retrieved 16 July 2011, from http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article33327846 Also senior community leaders made encouraging messages to the isolated students like Field Marshal [[Sir William Birdwood]]:
I earnestly advise you to take full advantage of the educational correspondence classes that are open to you and by which my two grand-daughters have started their education. Be guided by the help and valuable instruction to be derived from 'Our Rural Magazine' and do not forget that the country districts, handicapped as their people may be in many respects, have been responsible for many of the most able leaders in the public life of Australia."OUR RURAL MAGAZINE.". (18 October 1934). The West Australian (Perth, WA : 1879-1954), p. 14. Retrieved 16 July 2011, from http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article32812573
==See also== *[[School of the Air]] {{Portal |Children's literature}} ==Notes== {{Reflist}} [[Category:1926 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:1946 disestablishments in Australia]] [[Category:Australian children's magazines]] [[Category:Australian monthly magazines]] [[Category:Defunct magazines of Australia]] [[Category:Distance education in Australia]] [[Category:Education magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1926]] [[Category:Magazines disestablished in 1946]] [[Category:Media in Perth, Western Australia]] {{Child-mag-stub}}

revision.comment: added the engineering departments of university of the aegean
revision.text:
The '''Polytechnic''' ([[Greek language|Greek:]] Πολυτεχνείο) is the traditional name for institutions of higher [[education in Greece]], dealing with [[engineering]] at the undergraduate and postgraduate levels. There are currently two polytechnics that operate as independent (public) [[universities]] [http://web.uni-marburg.de/eurostudies/studienreform/eaie_cd/ACE_CoE_CD_2005/acebook/NARIC_guide.pdf NARIC guide on Higher Education Systems in the European Union,Edition of 1999] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081209072945/http://web.uni-marburg.de/eurostudies/studienreform/eaie_cd/ACE_CoE_CD_2005/acebook/NARIC_guide.pdf |date=2008-12-09 }} and five polytechnic schools that belong to universities. They consist mainly of [[Engineering]] [[Academic department|department]]s and their undergraduate programs have a duration of 5 years (full-time). The legal framework of their operation is the same as the one of the universities, and their graduates have equal rights with the graduates of public Greek universities{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}}
Greek polytechnics are also referred to as ''Technical Universities''. == Polytechnics in Greece == === [[National Technical University of Athens]] === * School of Architectural Engineering * School of Applied Mathematical and Physical Sciences * School of Chemical Engineering * School of Civil Engineering * School of Electrical and Computer Engineering * School of Mechanical Engineering * School of Mining Engineering and Metallurgy * School of Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering * School of Rural and Surveying Engineering === [[Technical University of Crete]] === * School of Architectural Engineering * School of Electrical and Computer Engineering * School of Environmental Engineering * School of Mineral Resources Engineering * School of Production Engineering and Management === Polytechnic School of the [[University of Patras]] === * Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering * Department of Architectural Engineering * Department of Chemical Engineering * Department of Civil Engineering * Department of Computer Engineering and Informatics * Department of Mechanical and Aeronautical Engineering * Sciences Department === [[School of Engineering, AUTH|Polytechnic School]] of the [[Aristotle University of Thessaloniki]] === * Department of Architecture * Department of Chemical Engineering * Department of Civil Engineering * Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering * Department of Mechanical Engineering * Department of Rural and Surveying Engineering * Department of Spatial Planning and Development Engineering * Department of Mathematics, Physics and Computational Sciences === Polytechnic School of the [[University of the Aegean]]=== * Department of Information and Communication Systems Engineering * Department of Product and Systems Design Engineering * Department of Financial and Management Engineering === Polytechnic School of the [[University of Thessaly]]=== * Department of Architectural Engineering * Department of Civil Engineering * Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering * Department of Mechanical Engineering * Department of Urban Planning and Regional Development === Polytechnic School of the [[Democritus University of Thrace]] === * Department of Civil Engineering * Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Engineering * Department of Environmental Engineering * Department of Architectural Engineering * Department of Production and Management Engineering === Polytechnic School of the [[University of Western Macedonia]] === * Department of Mechanical Engineering * Department of Engineering Informatics and Telecommunications === Polytechnic School of the [[University of Ioannina]] === * Department of Computer Science and Engineering * Department of Architectural Engineering * Department of Materials Science and Engineering == See also == * [[Education in Greece]] * [[List of universities in Greece|Institutions of highest education in Greece]] * [[Apolytirion|Apolytirio and Panhellenic examinations]] * [[Polytechnic (United Kingdom)]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.ntua.gr/index_en.html NATIONAL TECHNICAL UNIVERSITY OF ATHENS] * [http://www.upatras.gr/index/page/id/8/lang/en Polytechnic Faculties (School of Engineering), University of Patras] * [http://en.tuc.gr/ Technical University of Crete: Technical University of Crete] [[Category:Education in Greece]]

{{notability|Companies|date=November 2018}} {{UDP|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox company | name = PrepClass | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_padding = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | trading_name = | native_name = | native_name_lang = <!-- Use ISO 639-1 code, e.g. "fr" for French. For multiple names in different languages, use {{Lang|[code]|[name]}}. --> | romanized_name = | former_name = | type = | traded_as = | ISIN = | industry = [[Education technology]] Edu-tech | genre = | fate = | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = 2013 | founder = Chukwuwezam Obanor and Olumide Ogunlana | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location = | hq_location_city = [[Lagos]] | hq_location_country = [[Nigeria]] | num_locations = | num_locations_year = <!-- Year of num_locations data (if known) --> | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = | products = | brands = | production = | production_year = <!-- Year of production data (if known) --> | services = | revenue = | revenue_year = <!-- Year of revenue data (if known) --> | operating_income = | income_year = <!-- Year of operating_income data (if known) --> | net_income = <!-- or: | profit = --> | net_income_year = <!-- or: | profit_year = --><!-- Year of net_income/profit data (if known) --> | aum = <!-- Only for financial-service companies --> | assets = | assets_year = <!-- Year of assets data (if known) --> | equity = | equity_year = <!-- Year of equity data (if known) --> | owner = | members = | members_year = <!-- Year of members data (if known) --> | num_employees = | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | module = <!-- Used to embed other templates --> | ratio = <!-- Basel III ratio, for BANKS ONLY --> | rating = <!-- credit rating, for BANKS ONLY --> | website = {{URL|https://prepclass.com.ng/}} | footnotes = | intl = <!-- Set positively ("true"/"yes"/etc) if company is international, otherwise omit --> }}
'''PrepClass''' is a Nigerian [[Educational technology|Edu-tech]] company.<ref>{{cite news | last =Sam | first =Wakoba | title =Nigeria’s PrepClass Wants All Candidates to Pass their University Entry Exams | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''techmoran.com''| date =4 August 2014 | url =https://techmoran.com/prepclass/ | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Shakirudeen | first =Taiwo | title =Nigerian education tech startup receives N98 million grant| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''pulse.ng''| date =4 May 2017 | url =http://www.pulse.ng/bi/tech/prepclass-nigerian-education-tech-startup-receives-n98-million-grant-id6625503.html | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Nigeria: Four Nigerians On Forbes Young Entrepreneurs 2016 List| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''allafrica.com''| date =5 October 2016 | url =http://allafrica.com/stories/201610050514.html | accessdate =26 May 2018}}</ref>
==History== PrepClass was founded on May 1, 2013 in Lagos, Nigeria by two friends, namely Chukwuwezam Obanor and Olumide Ogunlana both graduates of the [[University of Lagos]].<ref>{{cite news | last =Atoke | first = | title =BN Making It!: ‘Wezam & Olumide of PrepClass Are Changing the Face of Nigerian Education as You Know It| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''bellanaija.com''| date =31 May 2016 | url =https://www.bellanaija.com/2016/05/bn-making-it-wezam-olumide-of-prepclass-are-changing-the-face-of-nigerian-education-as-you-know-it/ | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref> The idea was developed when the [[Joint Admissions and Matriculation Board]] (JAMB) in [[Nigeria]] announced the birth of computer-based tests. The two friends saw an avenue to help students and learners prepare for tests and examinations online and thus, created a ‘test prep’ platform to help change, shape and improve the educational system in the country. This attempt later developed and led the creation of PrepClass<ref>{{cite news | last =Julia | first =Reynolds-Cuellar | title =Successful MIT Global Startup Labs alum visits campus| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''news.mit.edu''| date =29 August 2014 | url =http://news.mit.edu/2014/mit-global-startup-labs-invites-back-alum/ | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref>
In January 2018, an App called ''Prep-test'' was developed by the PrepClass team. It provides tutors with a platform where they are able to create and upload contents as text, image, audio-visuals (videos).<ref>{{cite news | last =Ifeanyi | first =Ndiomewese | title =PrepClass is addressing Nigeria’s educational issues one student-tutor relationship at a time| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''techpoint.ng''| date =19 June 2017 | url =https://techpoint.ng/2017/06/19/prepclass-solve-nigeria-education/ | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref>
===Funding=== In February 2014, the co-founders of Prepclass entered and won their first competition which was the ''Techcabal Battlefield''. The company received a $20,000 cash prize.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =7 TechCabal Battlefield Finalists Emerge to Contest For $20,000| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''bellanaija.com''| date =17 February 2014 | url =https://www.bellanaija.com/2014/02/seven-techcabal-battlefield-finalists-emerge-to-contest-for-20000-finale-holds-on-friday-21st-february-2014/ | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Startup Prepclass Emerges Winner Of Techcabal Battlefield $20,000| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''thebusinessaim.com.ng''| date =29 May 2017| url =http://thebusinessaim.com.ng/startup-prepclass-emerges-winner-of-techcabal-battlefield-20000/ | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref>
The innovation of the firm was also able to attract another $12,500 of equity free funding for emerging as the overall grand prize winner from [[Africa]] in the Indian-Africa competition which held later in 2014.<ref>{{cite news | last =Odunayo | first =Eweniyi | title =PrepClass: Life After The Battlefield | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''techcabal.com''| date =2 July 2014| url =https://techcabal.com/2014/07/02/prepclass-life-after-battlefield/ | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref>
In 2015, PrepClass was selected for the GSMA Ecosystem Accelerator Innovation Fund where they were awarded $322,000 grant.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Winning! PrepClass Awarded GSMA Ecosystem Accelerator Innovation Fund’s $322,000 Grant | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''bellanaija.com''| date =6 May 2017| url =https://www.bellanaija.com/2017/05/winning-prepclass-awarded-gsma-ecosystem-accelerator-innovation-funds-322000-grant/ | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref> With this grant, the edu-tech company will be moving to the next phase in its business evolution. <ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Announcing the first start-ups selected by our GSMA Ecosystem Accelerator Innovation Fund | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''gsma.com''| date =27 April 2017| url =https://www.gsma.com/mobilefordevelopment/programme/ecosystem-accelerator/announcing-the-first-start-ups-selected-by-our-gsma-ecosystem-accelerator-innovation-fund/ | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref>
==Services== PrepClass offers customized learning program for students and professionals.<ref>{{cite news | last =Amin | first =Glamtek| title =We need funding, mentorship —Tech start-ups | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''vanguardngr.com''| date =8 October 2014 | url =https://www.vanguardngr.com/2014/10/need-funding-mentorship-tech-start-ups/ | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =DoviLearn: Nigerian startup redefining education through E-learning | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''dailypost.ng''| date =5 September 2017 | url =http://dailypost.ng/2017/09/05/dovilearn-nigerian-startup-redefining-education-e-learning/ | accessdate =26 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Olawale | first =Adeyina | title =PrepClass Wins $20,000 At The TechCabal Battlefield Competition | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''techcityng.com''| date =5 February 2015 | url =https://www.techcityng.com/prepclass-wins-20000-techcabal-battlefield-competition/ | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref> The company also provides access to personal home tutors for parents on demand.<ref>{{cite news | last =Opudo | first =Denis | title =Top 10 Leading African Edutech Startups | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''techinafrica.com''| date = | url =http://www.techinafrica.com/top-10-leading-african-edutech-startups/ | accessdate =26 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Lawal | first =Fu'ad | title =9 Nigerian startups selected for residency, could get up to $1.5 million | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''pulse.ng''| date =7 November 2017 | url =http://www.pulse.ng/news/tech/xl-africa-9-nigerian-startups-selected-for-residency-could-get-up-to-1-5-million-id7566586.html | accessdate =26 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Daniel | first =Anuoluwapelumi Moses | title =Meet 5 tech start-ups improving education in Nigeria | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''techmoran.com''| date =20 October 2017 | url =https://techmoran.com/meet-5-tech-start-ups-improving-education-nigeria/ | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Ifeanyi | first =Ndiomewese | title =PrepClass receives $322,000 grant from the GSMA Ecosystem Accelerator Innovation fund | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''techpoint.ng''| date =3 May 2017 | url =https://techpoint.ng/2017/05/03/prepclass-receives-grant/ | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref> Prepclass and its app has created a huge archive of locally relevant contents for students across Nigeria and Africa.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =PrepClass: The Journey So Far| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''techcabal.com''| date =20 April 2016 | url =https://techcabal.com/2016/04/20/prepclass-the-journey-so-far/ | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref> Simultaneously, through Prepclass, new job opportunities are being created in Nigeria.<ref>{{cite news | last =Gabriella | first =Mulligan | title =Third time lucky for Prepclass founder| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''disrupt-africa.com''| date =8 June 2016 | url =http://disrupt-africa.com/2016/06/third-time-lucky-for-prepclass-founder/ | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Agunbiade | first =Tola | title =Say Hello To GreenHouse Capital, Venture Garden Group’s Funding Vehicle| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''techcabal.com''| date =12 August 2016 | url =https://techcabal.com/2016/08/12/say-hello-to-greenhouse-capital-venture-garden-groups-funding-vehicle/| accessdate =26 May 2018}}</ref>
==Awards and recognitions== * In 2014, Prepclass was named one of the ''Top Ten Most Innovative Companies'' in Africa by [[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]].<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =The Top 10 Most Innovative Companies In Africa | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''fastcompany.com''| date =4 February 2014 | url =https://www.fastcompany.com/3026686/the-top-10-most-innovative-companies-in-africa | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref>
* In 2016, Ogunlana Olumide & Chukwuwezam Obanor the co-founders of PrepClass were named by [[Forbes]] Africa among its ''30 most promising young entrepreneurs'' in Africa.<ref>{{cite news | last =Mfonobong | first =Nsehe | title =30 Most Promising Young Entrepreneurs In Africa 2016 | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''forbes.com''| date = | url =https://www.forbes.com/sites/mfonobongnsehe/2016/04/25/30-most-promising-young-entrepreneurs-in-africa-2016/8/#78dd2ed962dc | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref>
* In 2017, Prepclass was selected for two start-up accelerator initiatives:
# [[Co-Creation Hub|CCHUB]] Pitch Drive - an initiative by Google for Entrepreneurs and [[Google]] to help 14 African start-ups in Europe raise 20 million Euros in funding.<ref>{{cite news | last =Shakirudeen | first =Taiwo | title =14 African tech start-ups begin campaign to raise €20 million investment across Europe | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''pulse.ng''| date =17 August 2017 | url =http://www.pulse.ng/bi/tech/pitch-drive-14-african-tech-start-ups-begin-campaign-to-raise-20-million-investment-across-europe-id7156443.html | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref> # XL partners Africa – an initiative by the [[World Bank]] to help 20 digital scale-ups from across the continent.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =8 Nigerian Startups selected for World Bank Group’s Digital Acceleration Program | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''bellanaija.com''| date =6 November 2017 | url =https://www.bellanaija.com/2017/11/8-nigerian-startups-selected-world-bank-groups-digital-acceleration-program/ | accessdate =15 May 2018}}</ref>

[[File:Whitehousephotoofficejune.png|thumb|2010 Presidential Scholars with President [[Barack Obama]]]] [[File:Presscholars05.png|thumb|2005 Presidential Scholars with President [[George W. Bush]]]]
The '''United States Presidential Scholars Program''' is a program of the [[United States Department of Education|Department of Education]]. It is described as "one of the Nation's highest honors for students" in the [[United States|United States of America]] and the globe.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ed.gov/programs/psp|title=U.S, Presidential Scholars Program.|publisher=U.S. Department of Education}}</ref>
The program was established in 1964 by Executive Order of the [[President of the United States]] to recognize the most distinguished graduating seniors for their accomplishments in many areas: academic success, leadership, and service to school and community. In 1979, it was expanded to recognize students who demonstrate exceptional scholarship and talent in the visual, creative, and performing arts. In 2015, the program was expanded once again to recognize students who demonstrate ability and accomplishment in career and technical fields. In the recent past, the organization has welcomed nominations from individual recommenders of the students' own choosing regardless of whether these students' academic results or achievements otherwise qualified them for recognition; however, per the organization's website, at present, "application for the U.S. Presidential Scholars Program is by invitation only. Students may not apply individually to the program or be nominated (outside of the above process)."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www2.ed.gov/programs/psp/eligibility.html|title=Eligibility.|publisher=U.S. Department of Education}}</ref> Annually, the presidentially-appointed White House Commission on Presidential Scholars chooses up to 161 U.S. Presidential Scholars from among that year's senior class. All Scholars are invited to Washington, DC in June for the National Recognition Program, featuring various events and enrichment activities and culminating in the presentation of the Presidential Scholars Medallion during a White House-sponsored ceremony.
To commemorate their achievements, the scholars are individually awarded the Presidential Medallion in a ceremony sponsored by the [[White House]].
==Selection process==
All candidates are invited to apply to the program in January of their graduation year. Applications are due in February. Semifinalists are announced in Mid-April and all Scholars are announced the first week of May. The National Recognition Program in Washington, DC usually occurs in June.
An overview of selection progression follows:
{| class="wikitable" !Designation !Number of candidates !Ratio !Percent |- | Graduating senior | 3,000,000 <small>(approx.)</small> eligible to apply | 1 in 1 | 100% |- | Presidential Scholar Candidate | 2600 <small>(approx.)</small> | 1 in 1,500 | 0.0667% |- | Presidential Scholar Semifinalist | 500 <small>(approx.)</small> | 1 in 6,000 | 0.0167% |- | Presidential Scholar | 121 in academics, 20 in arts, 20 in career & technical education | 1 in over 18,000 | 0.00537% |}
===General=== All graduating high school seniors who are citizens of the United States or legal permanent residents around the globe, enrolled in either private or public high schools, and who have scored exceptionally well on either the [[SAT]] of the [[College Board]] or the [[ACT (examination)|ACT Assessment]] of the [[American College Testing Program]] on or before October of each year are automatically considered for participation.
The [[United States Department of Education]] then examines the test records for the top 30 males and top 30 females in each state/jurisdiction. The combined file of scores from the top male examinees and top female examinees are then ranked from high to low in each state. The scores associated with the top 20 male examinees and top 20 female examinees are used to identify the candidates in each state. When ties occur in the threshold score, more than 20 persons of that gender are invited in that state. In addition, each Chief State School Officer (CSSO) may nominate up to ten male and ten female candidates, residing in the CSSO's jurisdiction, based on their outstanding scholarship. Additionally, the program is partnering with several recognition organizations that will each nominate up to 10 candidates from their individual programs. Each year approximately 4,000 students are invited to apply to the program.
Candidates then go through a rigorous application process where they must submit candidacy materials, including essays, self-assessments, secondary school reports, and transcripts. Candidates are evaluated on their academic achievement, personal characteristics, leadership, service, and other extracurricular activities, and an analysis of their essays.
In mid-April approximately 800 Semifinalists are chosen by a review committee of qualified individuals experienced in secondary and post-secondary education. Six to twenty Semifinalists are identified for each state/jurisdiction. The number of Semifinalists identified per state/jurisdiction is proportionate to the number of candidates for that state.
In May, the White House Commission on Presidential Scholars makes the final selection of up to 161 Presidential Scholars. One male student and one female Scholar are chosen from the world, the [[District of Columbia]], the [[Commonwealth of Puerto Rico]], and from families of U.S. citizens and from citizens living abroad. In addition, up to fifteen Scholars are chosen [[at-large]].
===Arts===
====Overview==== The [[YoungArts|National YoungArts Foundation]] reviews approximately 12,000 candidates annually of 15- to 18-year-old artists in the fields of visual, literary, performing and design arts.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} From these they select (through a blind adjudication process) the top 600-700 artists in the nation as National Winners. 171 of these Winners travel to [[Miami, Florida]] for National YoungArts Week, where they are further adjudicated by panelists and can win up to $10,000 to help them pursue a career in the arts. These 171 Winners are then narrowed down to 60 nominees that are recommended to the White House Commission on Presidential Scholars. These 60 candidates are invited to apply, and the Commission, in turn, selects the 20 U.S. Presidential Scholars in the Arts.
====Selection==== Students must register and participate in YoungArts, a national program of the National Young Arts Foundation designed to identify, recognize and encourage talented high school seniors who demonstrate excellence in cinematic arts, dance, design, jazz, music, photography, theater, vocal performance, visual arts or writing.
Based on the discipline entered, registrants must submit audiotapes, videotapes, slides or manuscripts demonstrating artistic accomplishment. One panel for each arts discipline evaluates applicants in a two-step blind adjudication process. The judges review material submitted by the applicants and select up to 20 award candidates in each of the ten disciplines for live adjudications in Miami (YoungArts also has National Merit and Honorable Mention Winners that can attend one of three Regional Programs in Los Angeles, New York City and Miami, Florida, as well). All applicants are judged against a standard of excellence within each artistic discipline, not against each other.
The final judging from the National YoungArts Week results in the recognition of excellence in five different award categories. Upon completion of the YoungArts program, YoungArts will nominate up to sixty students who meet the eligibility requirements for the U.S. Presidential Scholars Program. These students will be mailed candidacy materials and invited to apply to the program.
To be considered further, candidates must submit candidacy materials, including essays, self-assessments, secondary school reports, and transcripts. Candidates are evaluated on their academic achievement, personal characteristics, leadership, service, and extracurricular activities, and an analysis of their essays.
Arts candidates enter the U.S. Presidential Scholars Program selection process at the semifinalist level. In April the White House Commission on Presidential Scholars makes the final selection of up to twenty U.S. Presidential Scholars in the Arts. ==Career and technical education== In 2015, the program was again extended to recognize students who demonstrate ability and accomplishment in career and technical education fields. Students are nominated through their Chief State School Officer (CSSO). Each CSSO can nominate up to five candidates who meet the U.S. Presidential Scholars candidacy requirements for the 2016 program. Candidacy materials are mailed to the selected students, and they are invited to apply to the program. To be considered further, candidates must submit candidacy materials, including essays, self-assessments, secondary school reports, and transcripts. Candidates are evaluated on their academic achievement, personal characteristics, leadership, service, and extracurricular activities, and an analysis of their essays. Career and Technical Education candidates enter the U.S. Presidential Scholars Program selection process at the semifinalist level. In April the White House Commission on Presidential Scholars makes the final selection of up to twenty U.S. Presidential Scholars in Career and Technical Education.
==Prominent scholars==
===Academic=== *[[Richard Alley]] (1976, Ohio) - geosciences professor at [[Pennsylvania State University]] *[[Dr.Wayne HILL]] (1996, Chicago, Nicosia Cyprus) - Head of Admission & Legal Affairs Department of [[Virginia state University 1996-2014]] , [[Mount William University 2014-2018]] *[[Patrick Chovanec]] (1988, Illinois) - business professor at [[Tsinghua University]], former aide to [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House]] [[John Boehner]] *[[Kristin Forbes]] (1988, New Hampshire) - business professor at [[MIT]], former member of [[Council of Economic Advisors]] *[[Kermit Roosevelt III]] (1989, District of Columbia) - author, law professor at [[University of Pennsylvania]] *[[Elizabeth Kiss]] (1979, Virginia) - eighth president of [[Agnes Scott College]], first female Warden of [[Rhodes House]], Oxford University and CEO of the [[Rhodes Trust]] *[[John Brad]] (1999, California) - president of [[American State University ]] *[[Dr. John McKenzie]] (2003, California) - Head of Scholarship and International Student Affair Department [[National Louis Mount University ]]
===Arts=== *[[Suzette Charles]] (1981, New Jersey) – [[Miss America]] 1984, singer and entertainer *[[Rita Dove]] (1970, Ohio) – [[Poet Laureate]] of the United States, winner of [[Pulitzer Prize for Poetry]] *[[Desmond Richardson]] (1986) – dancer, co-founder of [[Complexions Contemporary Ballet]] *[[Josh Singer]] (1990, Pennsylvania) – screenwriter<ref>{{cite news|last=Holmes|first=Kristen|title=Another Feather In Cap Of Former 'Nerd'|url=http://articles.philly.com/1990-05-27/news/25888232_1_highest-federal-honor-presidential-scholars-award|newspaper=Philadelphia Inquirer|date=May 27, 1990|accessdate=October 23, 2014}}</ref> *[[Conrad Tao]] (2011, New York) – pianist, composer and violinist
===Energy=== *[[Amory Lovins]] (1964, Massachusetts) - environmentalist, Chairman and Chief Scientist of the [[Rocky Mountain Institute]]
===Government and politics=== *[[Donald S. Beyer Jr.]] (1968, District of Columbia) - U.S. ambassador to [[Switzerland]] and [[Liechtenstein]], former [[Lieutenant Governor of Virginia]] *[[Mitch Daniels]] (1967, Indiana) - President of [[Purdue University]], former [[Governor of Indiana]], former Director of [[U.S. Office of Management and Budget]] *[[Bruce Reed (political operative)|Bruce Reed]] (1978, Idaho) - CEO of the [[Democratic Leadership Council]], former aide to President [[Bill Clinton]] *[[Merrick Garland]] (1970, Illinois) - Judge of the [[United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit]], [[Associate Justice]] nominee ===Technology=== *[[Clara Shih]] (2002, Illinois) – CEO of [[Hearsay Social]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.stanford.edu/news/2004/december8/Marshall-1208.html |title=Five students and recent graduates win Marshall Scholarships |publisher=''Stanford News'' |date=December 3, 2004 |first=Mark |last=Shwartz |accessdate=October 1, 2014 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.ed.gov/programs/psp/ U.S. Department of Education Presidential Scholars Program] *[http://www.presidentialscholars.org/ Presidential Scholars Alumni Association] *[http://www.ed.gov/programs/psp/awards.html Lists of past Presidential Scholars]

revision.text:
{{for|the concept in category theory|pushout (category theory)}}
A '''pushout''' is a student that leaves their [[school]] before graduation, through the encouragement of the school. A student who leaves of their own accord (e.g., to work or care for a child), rather than through the action of the school, is considered a school [[Dropping out|dropout]]. In typical use, the category of pushouts excludes students who have been formally [[Expulsion (academia)|expelled]] from school for violating rules (e.g., for being violent).
Students may be pushed out of school because their presence in the school creates difficulty in meeting some goal of the school. For example, in the case where funding for the school is dependent upon scholastic achievement of the students, if the school can get rid of low-performing students, average test scores on academic performance tests will go up, thus increasing funding.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2003/07/31/nyregion/to-cut-failure-rate-schools-shed-students.html "To Cut Failure Rate, Schools Shed Students"] by Tamar Lewin and Jennifer Medina, ''New York Times''. July 31, 2003.</ref> Schools may pushout [[truant]] students, who formally enroll in classes, but then refuse to attend.
In some low-performing schools in [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]] combined dropout/pushout rates have exceeded 25% in one year.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20030924235824/http://www.catalyst-chicago.org/06-99/069midyearchart.htm "Enrollment drops point to pushout effect", ''Catalyst, Voices of Chicago Educational Reform.'' June, 1999]</ref>
Children are also pushed from schools because they present [[School discipline|discipline]] problems. Within youth advocacy and activist communities, pushout is a term that recognizes the intersecting forces of oppression most commonly responsible for high school "drop outs" within marginalized communities of color, allowing for the responsibility to be placed on those forces, rather than the youth impacted by unequal education, economics, disciplinary actions, and racism.
==See also== *[[Dishonorable discharge]] *[[School-to-prison pipeline]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:School and classroom behaviour]]
